Cheating just points out that school discipline is quite separate from criminal prosecution.  I trust you understand a) Title IX requires the school to, in a timely fashion, launch their own investigation and b) the standards for judging the actions are those at the civil court level "preponderance of evidence", rather than the criminal prosecution level of guilty " without a reasonable doubt."  I think O.J. could support that these are very different requirements.  In my post, I specifically reference that many of these alleged rapes and sexual assualts involve "date" or "acquaintance" actions.  There are seldom wittnesses (not a big surprise).  The "rape kits" are usually irrelevant since the defense is almost always "yes, we had sex....but it was consensual."  You need to remember the schools have NO CHOICE but to launch a "genuine" investigation of their own.  It's required by Title IX. Your final sentence "....matter for the justice system, not academic institutions" is not true.

mc, if I were interested in arguing the matter in court in a legal setting, I would speak quite differently.  My comments comprise commentary on public policy and whether legislation itself is optimal.  I do not speak to McShane's ruling as it is constrained by existing statute.  Of course, it must be remembered that every statute must be interpreted and your comment that McShane is on target represents your interpretation of the law.  Obviously, lawyers for the school district argued contrary to your perspective.  If the matter is appealed to the ninth, we will get a more definitive decision on the matter.

But as I said, I am not interested in interpreting statute as written.  I am concerned with public policy which comes before and drives legislation.  Should society place some burden on the parents?  Is it best to mandate that schools delve into the treatment of mentally ill children?  I actually take no position on the matter, but raising the question is important.

Geez Boozer:  You need to learn a bit about tenant/landlord laws before making such comments.  1) When you rent/lease property you can only enter that property under very specific, legally defined, conditions.  Kicking open a locked door in the tenant's absence is not included in those defined conditions.  2) A landlord may file an FED (Forced Entry & Detainer) and follow the legal process to regain possession of his rented/leased property.  It's a very specific legal process and needs to be followed to regain legal possession.
3) The laws regarding storage facilities are quite different and specific.  They involve notifications, "over-locks" and a defined time line until the landlord is vested with "ownership" of stored property.  

Most importantly, being a landlord owed past-due rent, does not give an individual the authority to "break and enter" a property and remove a tenant's personal property.  The charges Mr. Hammer faces are hardly "laughable."

I hope you don't have any neighbors within at least a half mile or so and have worked out the fields of fire in your place so you don't shoot your wife, kids, or dog due to a miss or over-penetration.   Unless you live in the middle of nowhere, a rifle, any rifle, but especially one with a small, high-speed projectile like a .223, is a terrible home defense weapon unless there's a herd of zombies coming down your street.   A pistol with enough stopping power to actually defend you has the same over-penetration problems.   A 12 gauge with 7 or 8 birdshot will kill an intruder just as dead at true self-defense distances as buckshot, a rifle, or a heavy pistol, and it won't destroy your house or kill your neighbors, family, or pets.

This is a very dangerous idea. The next thing you know, teachers will start adapting to the needs of their individual classes and even to the needs of individual students. They will start using good judgment to do what is best for each student in each case. They will teach from their special strengths and design their courses and assessments in ways that build on the interests and motivations of the students they have. They might even involve the parents in making decisions about how best to understand and help their students move forward. 

This would be a disaster. It would be a threat to our industrial system of educational production, not to mention the profits of corporations who design assessment systems and build databases for the Entire Nation. William Seward wasn't necessarily seen as a "great white man" for buying Alaska. He was ridiculed about it until the rest of the United States realized that Alaska could make them rich. Seward saw Alaska's potential and fought for the U.S. to get hold of the land despite much criticism. It is true that Alaska Natives tribes were negatively impacted by colonialism in the past. We should be aware of what happened in history, learn from it, and not repeat it– but we can't change it. A statue of Seward should not stand to remind everyone of past injustices, but to recognize the perseverance and hard work it took to get us to where we are today.

ODFW:
Flotsam crab - Planes spp.  The rare pelagic crab

In Oregon, there are not many crabs living anywhere but the bottom of the sea or estuary. Flotsam crabs are the exception.
Two species are found in Oregon: Planes major (formerly P. cyaneus) and Planes marinus. Both species is known for living on floating debris (flotsam), derelict fishing gear, and even upon live animals (e.g. sea turtles).
When found it is often by those looking for glass floats, which these crab often live on, needless to say, Planes crab are a rare find.

aka. Columbus crab - Planes spp.

The species Planes marinus is by far rarer of the two species found in the Pacific Northwest (G. Jensen, pers comm.) This genus of crab is also referred to as "Columbus crabs"
Columbus and his crew, during their journey to the new world “saw much more weed appearing, like herbs from rivers, in which they found a live crab, which the Admiral kept. He says these crabs are certain signs of land…” (Markham, 1893)

Motley:  I know this comment is to some degree (I don't know how much of a degree) tongue in cheek.  However, many folks my age (73) are struggling to survive financially.  Many of their adult children are not in a position to provide much help to them.  I've seen seriors write checks to the pharmacy for several hundred dollars for medications which Midicare doesn't cover.  We've had elderly tenants who can barely pay their rent.  We've had tenants whose rent we didn't raise for ten or more years, knowing that they simply couldn't afford the increase.  

Please don't consider this "whining" (personally we're "holding our own") but, for many seniors, being both elderly and really poor is not much fun.  

I enjoy your comments and the many exchanges we've had over time.  However, I feel the issue of poverty among seniors is "no laughing matter."  thanks, Gary

I see Charles' excellent article as a metaphor. Its not whether campaign contributions less than $1,000 influence municipal candidates, it's about our largely unregulated federal campaign system. The Koch brothers alone have budgeted $889 million for the current presidential race. Large out-of-state donors now have outsized influence on who is elected to state supreme courts and legislatures. Corporations looking at a multi-billion dollar business deal, or a tax break that will save them hundreds of millions, make what to them are sound business decisions to contribute a few hundred thousand here and few hundred thousand there, looking for a tremendous return on investment. 

The only solution is meaningful regulation of contributions. And that requires  that the Supreme Court's 5-4 Citizen's United decision be overturned. Overturning Citizen's United may be the most important issue on which this presidential election should turn. The implications resound throughout our lives.

But if you look closer a dog is classified as level-1-aggressive if somebody filed a complaint saying they felt "threatened", which can mean anything -- including being barked at. It is not a level-2 or level-3, which are dogs who have actually bit somebody. So you are stretching things quite a bit by saying this dog has a "history of violence". Source: http://www.muni.org/Departments/health/Admin/animal_control/Documents/Codified%20Title%2017%20(54%20page%20PDF).pdf

If this dog were such a beast, then why are his neighbors not saying "good riddance", or "serves him right"? No, they are defending the dog owner because they know this dog was harmless and shooting him was a ridiculous over-reaction by a trigger happy idiot.

What I have never used or found useful are such things as quadratic equations,  matrix theory,  linear algebra, or elementary algebra (the symbol-manipulation rules taught in elementary courses of mathematics as part of primary and secondary education.  

I had not one instructor but a total of four (4) that I recall.  They were all quite pleased with themselves and really seemed to enjoy the subject matter, but never really showed me a use for what I had to memorize, manipulate and regurgitate.  Geometry was also learned with the same result.  If I ever wanted to know how tall a flagpole was or had to find myself on the ocean using a sextant and a watch, it could very well have been useful, but I never did either.

No longer seeking to trade work for cash...we now have panhandling - simply make a sign, stand on a corner and EXPECT people to give you money. It's really not about the unhoused or the addict needing treatment, those needs are already being worked on in almost every community, give money to those causes if inclined. Panhandling is asking/demanding/requesting your money -- without any exchange of effort or work, integrity no longer required.

It depends on how you structure the tax. If you make it a percentage of your federal tax owed (Form 1040, Line 56), then yes, half the population will pay nothing. 

If you make it a percentage of your taxable income (Line 43) then far more will pay. 

If you make it a percentage of your adjusted gross income (Line 37), nearly everyone will pay something.

For any major economic entity, including a person, a company or a government organization, there are reasons a credit rating matters.  In the case of the state, bonds are a significant mechanism to pay for capital projects.  If we chose never to use them, we will have to entirely self capitalize all our infrastructure and buildings.  That would dramatically increase our deficit and/or reduce our capital budgets to the point few would like the state of things such as roads and bridges.  The reality would be even worse than it sounds like, with life safety as well as economic impacts on things like employment.

I am very much a free market capitalist oriented theorist, and a charter member of the Libertarian party in Michigan, Montana and Washington state.  So I sympathize with your point of view substantially, in particular for people who move to Alaska.  But Alaska villages have many people who did NOT choose to live there:  they were born there.  The text of the treaty buying Alaska severely restricted development (outside of about 440 acres already developed) - the rest was held in trust for the sake of the native peoples.  The ANCSA may have properly addressed that issue (so we can develop more), but the spirit of the treaty remains, IMHO, as a requirement to respect the interests of the people born into those rural locations.  The transition from the stone age to the present era is much harder than most people can imagine and sociologists tell me it will take "at least 150 years" to complete gracefully.  Our obligations probably remain to some degree.

From Oregon Revised Statutes:
814.400 Application of vehicle laws to bicycles.
(1) Every person riding a bicycle upon a public way is subject to the provisions applicable to and has the same rights and duties as the driver of any other vehicle concerning operating on highways, vehicle equipment and abandoned vehicles, except:
(a) Those provisions which by their very nature can have no application.
(b) When otherwise specifically provided under the vehicle code.
(2) Subject to the provisions of subsection (1) of this section:
(a) A bicycle is a vehicle for purposes of the vehicle code; and
(b) When the term “vehicle” is used the term shall be deemed to be applicable to bicycles.

In 1974, the Commission designated the gill net fishery a "distressed fishery" under the Act. 20 AAC 5.300. Because the Board of Fish and Game closed the separate set net fishery in 1972, the Commission promulgated an emergency regulation pursuant to AS 44.62.250 on April 7, 1975, consolidating the two fisheries. This regulation allowed Southeast Alaska setnetters to apply for gill net entry permits based upon their participation as setnetters. The Commission would judge all applications for entry into the gill net fishery by the same criteria. See 20 AAC 05.300.

What you have with guns and suicidal individuals is a combination that ups the likelihood of death.  

First off, self-inflicted gunshot wounds are the most effective ways of killing oneself.  A Harvard study from 2001 found that 85% of those who attempted suicide this way were successful.  Suffocation (hanging) came in second at 69%.  All other methods were well below 50%.

Second the availability of guns increases the likelihood of attempting suicide.  It's quick and requires little pre-planning.  Guns play an outsized role in spontaneous suicides.  Someone in a momentary crisis situation with a tendency toward depression and perhaps under the influence of alcohol or drugs grabs a gun and it's over.  A noose requires work,  other means lead to prolonged periods between initiating the attempt and death, which gives time for an intervention or for the suicidal person to seek help.

2/3 of our gun deaths are suicides.  It's not anti-gun to acknowledge this and seek to fix it.

Aggregate demand increases with an increase in wage.  Since inflation on an aggregate level is around .04% with an increase in minimum wage, the benefit of the increased wages go directly into consumption because most low income earners have a high marginal propensity to consume.  That means they spend nearly all the income they earn and it flows back into the economy.  That compares to a working with low MPC (a doctor for example) that with an increase in income, the amount that flow back into the economy directly is only proportionate to what they are willing to spend and not the amount they are saving or investing.   In other words, if you increase wages at the bottom it flows back to the top offsetting the additional costs in the long run.  The problem is that it does take time for the changes to reach the long run outcome which is why there are incremental increases rather than one huge jump.

According to Maryland public records, Kenneth Allen Hern, 64, of Lowell, Oregon, was indicted last year on three counts in Howard County: importing between 5 and 45 kilograms (11 to 99 pounds) of marijuana, intent to distribute and possession. Bond was set at $150,000. The first and third charges have a recorded disposition of "Nolle Prosequi," which is Latin for "we shall no longer prosecute."

On the charge of intent to distribute, a felony in Maryland, a plea of guilty was entered on April 1, 2016, on Mr. Hern's behalf by Andrew Ira Alperstein, a Baltimore attorney. A jail term of 5 years was imposed and suspended. A 2-year supervised probationary period was imposed, along with 150 hours of community service to be served by April 1, 2018, and a $1,000 fine plus court costs. Probation supervision was transferred to Oregon.

Also, according to the PERS database, Mr. Hern retired January 1, 2003, after 341 months of service with a Tier One monthly benefit of $6,657, or $79,886 a year.

Minimum wage increases are far more insidious than than what has been posted here. For example, if Company A's costs are $1.00 to put a product on the market and they want 10% profit, cost of the item is $1.10. If the cost increases due to minimum wage to $1.10, the 10% profit now makes the item $1.21. That increase is, of course, passed on to the consumer. Now look what happens. The business' gross increases, which means they have to pay higher taxes at the end of the year. The minimum wage worker also has to pay higher taxes, and that increase outpaces the gains made by the minimum wage worker. The result? More tax money to the state and the worker falls even further behind. But wait, there's more. Many union wages are ties to minimum wage, meaning that their pay is based on a percentage added to minimum wage, i.e., their wages go up, forcing those companies to raise their prices. More tax dollars go to the state(and Fed.) But wait, there's more...

Plenty of guns on a military base. We just have enough common sense and experience to keep them locked up in an arms room, & well-separated from ammo stores, when we don't need them. Again, a common sense safety measure, as are the many countless hours of highly-supervised performance-oriented training troopers who are likely to engage in Close Quarters Battle (or any task involving things that go boom) must successfully complete prior to ever doing a live-fire exercise at combat speed. 

To think a lone "good guy" is going to have the technical and tactical proficiency to be successful in a stressful & confusing hostile shooter situation with a concealable sidearm is a fantasy fueled by fear & rhetoric. One that defies all logic & common sense. What we are more likely to see is an increase in accidental discharges, suicides, & inappropriate use.

"The cheapest and most certain way to reduce murder is the death penalty for murderers."  

I dispute this assertion vigorously.  Simple reason.  Most murders are committed by people who only offend once.  Yes, there are some serial killers, but most murders are from rage or circumstance that does not recur.  Other crimes are like this as well.  Commission of most crimes is by first time offenders.  The notion that killing offenders will reduce crime is largely without factual basis - it just feels good.

Teaching that human life can be forfeit on the false premise that it reduces crime, in my opinion, creates the very atmosphere wherein individuals are prone to take life.  Teach the taking of life and individuals will learn.  

Emotionally, i support killing those who resort to premeditated murder.  Rationally, I believe that each time we collectively kill we likely motivate and engender multiple killings between individuals who are simply applying what we collectively teach.
To be clear, I agree with the author of the piece.

While I am in agreement with the need to keep the officer and his/her family safe, this is not the way to do it. When police activities of any sort, let alone a shooting where someone dies, are allowed to be kept secret from public review, we risk abuse and tyranny. While it may seem prudent right now in this particular case, eventually a law like this in the hands of those who are entrusted with police power tends to become standard procedure. Once that happens abuse of the practice is certain to follow, and should it become widespread it becomes tyranny. It is a slippery slope.

Anyone who becomes a police officer knows what they sign up for when they take the job. Since this kind of thing happens rarely, the officer's name should still be released, but the officer and family should be protected as needed by moving them somewhere secure until the threat is sufficiently reduced. Yes, it is inconvenient, but only to a few. Tyranny, however, affects everyone and is not easily undone.

It seems that Anchorage may have outgrown her present "leash-laws".
I realize that this particular situation falls into a grey area: a poorly mannered dog in his electric-fenced yard, scares a new neighbor with a small child. Chaos ensues.

Last year we had a bizarre experience in the same grey area.  My crew joined my SIL, niece and dogs for a walk.  The dogs were unleashed and under voice-control.  She and I had looped a pond by a school and were approaching the playground, where my kids & hubby were playing. Both dogs were ten feet in front of us.  A man at the playground stepped out and smacked one dog with a ski pole and began screaming at us about leash laws.  She recalled her dogs, who sat at her side while the man continued to brandish the pole and scream. My Popeye-esque husband hustled over and his presence caused the man to lower his voice and his pole. We promptly left.

The laws need clarification before someone gets hurt.

This is certainly a topic which calls for commenters to identify at least whether they live in a single-family home and their immediate neighborhood context. 

As I've posted numerous times, I live in the old "Westside neighborhood in a 1929 house that was a trashed rental when I bought it. Our neighborhood was "red-lined" at the time, and there were almost no families with children. Many of us have fought hard to reestablish a vibrant, inclusive, compact neighborhood that supports home ownership, as well as welcoming renters who also love the neighborhood.

In the 1980s, the Eugene Planning Division had a culture that valued neighborhoods, especially the close-in ones that are subject to a lot of pressure from various impacts. That's all changed dramatically under Piercy and Ruiz, where our Planning Division is positively hostile towards neighborhood residents who want to protect and nourish their community. Instead, we have absurd fantasies like the proposed SW-SAZ zone.

This is crazy!   The only place in Alaska where clock time is even close to sun time is Southeast during Standard Time.   By the time you move westward to Anchorage, sun time is almost two hours off clock time.   By the time you get to Bethel, Nome, or Kotzebue it is three to four hours off clock time and even around the equinoxes the sun doesn't rise until ten or eleven AM and it is still light at midnight.   In ANC it is merely a bit disorienting, but in the Western parts of the State it has a dramatic effect on the way people live.   Daylight Savings Time is unnecessary and inconvenient, but the biggest thing it does is make the disassociation between sun time and clock time even worse.

While opinion articles are not bound by the normal rigors of journalistic fact checking, one would hope that a piece written by the Editorial Board would at least have its facts straight.
Tax revenue from recreational consumer sales do not pay for OLCC operation and regulation of the marijuana program. That is covered under the registration fees that are paid by everyone who owns a recreational marijuana business.
Furthermore the breakdown of the tax revenue is misleading. From the OLCC website the tax revenue is divided as follows:
40 % to Common School Fund, 
20 % to Mental Health Alcoholism and Drug Services, 
15 % to State Police, 
10 % to Cities for enforcement of the measure, 
10 % to Counties for enforcement of the measure, 
5 % to Oregon Health Authority for alcohol and drug abuse prevention. 
The taxes go to law enforcement and questionable drug prevention programs.  It's an issue that must be addressed in the legislature.

Ms. Spitz's comments reflect little understanding of toy collecting. There is nothing sexist or ageist about the hobby, or Mr. McClafferty. Admittedly, toy collectors are predominantly male and easily make up 90%+ of the hobby. But don't  jump to conclusions based on a simple statistic. 
Girls, and women, simply prefer to spend their money on things other than toys, and when it comes to matters economic, they tend to be much more pragmatic....say, opting to make that car payment before engaging in discretionary spending. That way, any loving girlfriend can drive her man to the show, where he can blow the paycheck on old Star Wars toys....
But that doesn't make collecting a sexist avocation. 
In fact, Mr. McClafferty's toy shows are very inviting to both genders and all age groups: it's a family affair. Mike has a rule at his toy shows: no vendor to vendor sales are permitted before the doors open to the general public. That way, nobody takes advantage if Grandma wants to sell as well.

Probably not. The death penalty makes people feel good, and it certainly exacts a toll of revenge, but it does nothing for prevention of crime. Indeed, laws in general do not prevent crime. The study shows that, since carry legislation passed in Colorado, the rate of forcible rape increased by 25 percent in 2012 and 36 percent in 2013. In Utah, campus rape increased nearly 50 percent between 2012 and 2013. By contrast, sexual assaults nationwide have been decreasing each year by approximately 3 percent. To be sure, this data doesn’t prove that allowing guns at universities and colleges in Utah and Colorado caused those crime increases. It now seems the West Eugene EmX (currently under construction) is two halves of two different routes.  

The planners have discovered that "feeding" River Rd, Hwy 99, and West 11th will require three buses every 10 minutes on 6th/7th Avenues, which is too big of a bus concentrated on these avenues.  So, the latest proposal I have heard is to feed 99 using 13th/11th to Chambers (from the downtown station), and feeding West 11th from 6th/7th to Garfield.  That means buses will crisscross on two parallel streets, only two blocks apart.  

Maybe they should have planned the overall system first, to avoid the apparent crisscrossing on the five block sections of Chambers and Garfield.  West 11th should be feed by 13th/11th, but the city council rejected that alternative several years ago; setting-up an appearance of halves of two different routes.

With all the years of planning, meetings, expense, etc. I now think the 6th/7th & W. 11th route never should have been available to the council.

The essential problem here is too many white people don't know what the law says. Pre-Columbian remains are to be handed over to the Confederated Tribes. Period. The trouble began when the county coroner decided the skeleton was that of a white man, despite an obsidian arrowhead buried in the pelvis. He sent a fragment of bone off for carbon dating and it came back 10,000 years old. So the lunatic fringe started trumpeting "White people were here first! We are the original indigenous persons!" Housing costs reflect the standard of living in the community.  In the Eugene area the costs of all goods and services are quite high.......not Portland, not Seattle and not the Bay Area, but still quite high.  For folks working at or near the minimum wage that creates real issues.

The idea of "affordable housing" is a dream and CANNOT BE ACHIEVED without significant public funding to support it.  Section 8 housing is an example.

However, at the price of bare land, with the costs of permits and systems development fees, and with the price of construction,  we will not see privately developed housing at "affordable prices" for lower income families.  It simply doesn't "pencil."  
Only if it made economic sense,  would there be privately developed "affordable housing" available.  So realistically, any plans to increase the availability of such housing must include that significant government spending, and today any additional taxation for any purpose is a very hard sell.

The bane of my high school classroom existence was English. All four years of it. Shakespeare tortured me like no other. Interpreting poems? For what practical purpose? Book reports? Ugh. Who gives a rat's?

But math and science? Loved them for their paths of least resistance. Numbers made sense. No subjectivity. Smart, dorky guys with pocket protectors and slide rules were putting men on the moon. I went to college to study math.

Four decades later, the written word, not numbers, still provides for my sustenance. How can that be? Receiving an excellent public education built on a foundation of good teachers, a few great ones, all of whom challenged me. They made everything relevant, from English to art to music appreciation to shop to history to French to physics. Even Sir William himself. Most of their diplomas had "State College" on them. They weren't academic stars. They just cared.

Mr. Holland wasn't a myth. Quality teachers matter. So does algebra. Let's not settle for less.

Alaskans who purchase insurance through the ACA marketplace (including my wife and me) are hit with a double-whammy: 1. Health care costs in Alaska are very high, and 2. The risk pool over which these costs are spread is very small. This bill is good in that it spreads the high costs that some patients incur over a larger population.  However, it would be even better if the 23,000 or so patients in the ACA market could join larger pools.  Remember, the way you drive down medical costs is by combining as many patients as possible into one single pool, and then that pool of patients will have more bargaining power when negotiating cost of care from physicians, medical centers, pharmaceutical firms, etc.  Almost every other developed nation has single payer plans like that, and that is why their health care is so much less expensive and of equal or better quality than here.

Jacqueline Pynes asks, "Why should the state push people to vote who are not interested enough to make the effort to register to vote under the current system, which already takes minimal effort? 
Here's the answer: because the role of the state in a democracy, however mediocre and dysfunctional the institutions of that democracy might be, is to promote the welfare of the general public. Voting is a public good. Automatically registering citizens to vote does no harm. The state should make it as easy as possible for citizens to participate in elections. As citizens participate more, they will see the wisdom of informing themselves on the issues. This is exactly what anti-voting rights people fear.
That people actually have a problem with making it easier for citizens to vote is a measure of the backward mentalites--extreme individualism, laissez-faire racism, anti-government paranoia--that prevail here and prevent American society from moving into the 21st century.

The idea of harm should feature prominently in any discussion of LGBT rights but it has faded into oblivion here. Charles Wohlforth writes that "Judge Victor Carlson's career was destroyed because he was gay." Now that's real and long-lasting harm.  Being denied employment because you are gay is real harm. Being evicted or denied a place to live is real harm. Living in fear that you will be mocked and vilified is to suffer real harm. Being mocked and vilified is even worse. Judge Carlson very probably refuses to name his husband because of the harm he fears the man might suffer. My guess is that Judge Carlson allowed himself to be interviewed because he feels he is economically secure and less vulnerable to harm than other members of the LGBT community. The national debate about wedding cakes isn't really about speech, it's about harm. The fight isn't about whether anti-LGBT views will remain socially acceptable -- it's about whether they will continue to cause harm.

It seems that the expansion of moose between 1880's and 1940's could not be largely attributed to moose following expanding shrubs.  The areas where this expansion took place seem to be below tree line, and to a large extent in boreal forest areas.  This would lead to reasonable hypothesis that there is other, very significant factors effecting changes in moose ranges.  

Larger shrubs at the very northern edge of their range may certainly be a influencing factor out on that very edge, but is probably not the only, or even the largest factor effecting changes in the distribution of moose over the past 135 years.

Under President Bill Clinton the Omnibus Reconciliation Act of 1993 set up a phase in of direct lending. Many schools volunteered for the program, but the 104th Congress passed legislation to prevent the switch to 100% direct lending in 1994"  Under the Obama Administration's new budget, all new loan originations are under the Direct Loan program by July 2010, netting $6B in annual savings. The bill approving the measure passed the House of Representatives on September 17, 2009.  The switch to 100% Direct Lending effective July 1, 2010 was enacted by the Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010."

Well, at some point a lack of adequate clothing becomes a distraction in the classroom. This is one small part of a larger issue. The power and authority in schools has been slowly and imperceptibly shifted from the teachers and administrators to the students. This is fairly new. You see it in the curriculum and pretty much everywhere in the schools. This week our kid's school has a "student-led" parent-teacher conference. The students are making most of the decisions themselves, and it shouldn't be a surprise that they often don't make good choices. This shift of power and responsibility is great for the teacher and staff; they claim to be empowering the students but really it's just much easier in many ways. Enforcing a dress code would be a lot of work!

Hi Cydney. The 60's were very different for me. My family had moved to a much bigger town and larger school district. My elementary and intermediate years were done in a small 2 room school One teacher taught 1-4th grade and the other taught 5th-8th grade. Our bus driver was our music, PE and art teacher, so it was like a big family. The kids in the 4th grade and 8th grade, became assistant instructors and help the younger kids out, so the teacher never had to stop the lessons. It worked very well, not to mention it helped create a sense of citizenship and community. We can never go back to those days and I'm sure glad I don't have to attend the schools we have today. There are some lessons to learn from those times but education today doesn't understand the concept nor do they have a base for such perception. It can't be fixed but I feel bad for the youngsters now days. How is it that any 2-3 year old can tell you what they want to be but by the 6th grade they no longer care!

You are confusing cause and effect. Most homeless people are not addicted to anything. If they drink or use other mood altering drugs it's usually to relieve the extreme stress of being homeless. 

Formerly homeless Springfield resident Kirk Toncray, in his book "Behind the Signs", wrote, "I have often thought of what I would say when someone asked why most homeless people drink. I would have to answer: When it's twenty five degrees at three in the afternoon, and you are looking forward to a night with the low temperatures dipping into the single digits, catching a little buzz makes things a little more bearable. That probably sounds awful. If it does sound awful, try sleeping on and under nothing but cardboard for a week in that kind of weather. You'll get it." 

Most homeless people are victims of a dysfunctional economy. We need a lot more affordable housing, the lack of which is a local and national crisis.

Aikens history went from the Paiutes to the arrival of settlers in the 1840's bypassing the trapping period from 1810-40. A relative of mine, Louis Pichette, trapped the region for Hudson's Bay Co. He was the first Euro-American in Northeast CA (1820). 

The Paiutes were considered to be more primitive than many other tribes in the Oregon Territory. This was because of their transitory camps and desire to avoid contact. Resources were scarce with little surplus. They rarely traded but raiding was an honored practice. 

What ties the op-ed and its comments together is the different rate of exploitation practiced by natives and Euro-Americans. The trappers were a bridge. Over-harvesting the regions fur bearers infuriated the Paiutes. 

A Marxist interpretation adds to this thesis. Capitalism ramps up the rate of resource  extraction and often leads to systemic degradation. This is the Euro-American legacy.  The opinions here reflect different views on its value.

mc.  a rape victim testifying that a particular person has raped her and a confession from the "perp" is certainly enough to convict - at least historically.    If on the other hand, the perp says he didn't do it, DNA tests are needed and necessary to prove that he did it.  I fully support testing in every contested case as it would be material.  Even in cases where the perp confesses to a forcible rape, I support testing of rape kits so that past rapes by the perp might be identified, but if Joe and Jane admit having non-violent, non-forceful sex, but Jane later claims it was not consensual while Joe claims it was, rape kit evaluation (as in DNA analysis) is not material.  I suspect that rape kits in all violent or forceful rapes are routinely tested, while it is only Joe and Jane cases that are not.  If you support rape kit testing to catch rapists from other cases, it would be more effective to support universal DNA testing and creation of a national DNA database.

Your wish has already been granted and has been since 1983 when the portion of Alaska lying in the former Alaska Time Zone permanently advanced clocks one hour.  If you live in Anchorage you are on DST year-round and on "double DST" now.   Areas to the West in the former Bering Time Zone advanced clocks two hours permanently in 1983 and today they are on "triple daylight saving time.  The "winners" in 1983 were the people in Southeast who permanent turned back clocks one hour and returned to the former Yukon Time Zone where the time of day and position of the Sun coincide.  However, they are now the biggest "whiners" because they want to return to the Pacific Time Zone where they were from WWII to 1983.    I have pointed out that if position of the Sun and time of day mean anything, we in most of Alaska have done enough. ....in late 2014, federal lawmakers responded to the dilemma in another way: They made it possible to cut retiree benefits. The Multiemployer Pension Reform Act, tucked into a huge omnibus spending bill and passed without public hearings or debate, set up a mechanism through which pension trustees could propose a plan to reduce monthly payments. Backed by a coalition of pension plan trustees, unions, and employers, this approach will stretch the dwindling assets of troubled funds further into the future. But for retirees, most of whom knew little or nothing about the change in law as it was happening, it means benefits they earned could go up in smoke.

Bond measure funds are not used to fund salary and retirement.  I believe that Junction City retired it's only bond measure a few years ago. The biggest complaint I have is that it doesn't go far enough...it appears that it's a real piecemeal approach to structural improvements that need to be made across the school district.

I've lived in the district for decades, and taught for nearly thirty years in the high school, I'm certainly concerned about the lack of earthquake preparedness in the basic bond package. I always told my seniors that if an earthquake happened while they were in my classroom in the east wing, they were probably toast. How does a 220 lb. lineman fit under a middle-school-sized desk to "grab and hold?" When the masonry that holds up the outside wall collapses, what are the chances that they will be able to file out of the building in an orderly manner. Just a few among many survivability issues. 

Nonetheless, give this limited bond measure a yes. Please.

I still don't know if I would have supported the district had it made it to the ballot. But I think some would benefit from a little bit of fact-based thought.  I live in Elmira, about eight miles from Veneta. Veneta now contracts with the sheriff for a total of four deputies. Since Sheriff Trapp says it requires 5.2 FTE to assure 24/7 coverage (allowing for shift overlap, vacations, training, sick leave, other time away from patrol) Veneta actually has a little less than 24 hour coverage from one deputy seven days a week. That is roughly the same standard that is available in the county. However where I live, we have  three deputies providing coverage for the entire county (as observers noted about the size of Connecticut). Under the district proposal, my service would have increased substantially; the service in Veneta would have probably decreased, since the deputy on duty would have had a larger area to cover.

There's a minor discrepancy in the location of these endeavors at
the Harding Ice Field; given Bear Glacier is quite a distance from
the Exit Glacier location, even by snow machine. Or helicopter.

An emergency cabin (no heat, just shelter) has been in place at
the edge of Harding Ice Field where the highest trail from Exit
Glacier route ends. This is a study structure, prefabricated of
fitted treated wood with cables holding it down; as the wind
& most weather conditions there (west of Seward city) are bad.
They seldom are really all that good. This is where the ?-fated
trekkers way out at Bear Glacier should have gone for practice.

Yul Kilcher & a group of Peninsula adventurers, trekked from
Homer to Seward side of Harding Ice Field in early 1960s; made
camp on ice, + did well because they knew it's always winter there.

The persons in the story linked in comments, are known to me;
and I've been here for more than 55 years, in semi-rural Alaska.
Nothing's left of any older camps.

I picked up a large tree branch and rock and yelled that if her dogs attacked my dog I would kill them (I didn't have a firearm then).  She stared at us like a deer in headlights, doing nothing.   As my dog prepared to defend, I ducked behind my bike.   Then I screamed that if she didn't do something, I would bash in her skull after I killed her dogs.  Then, after what seemed like an eternity, she woke up and called them away.   Unbelievable that I actually had to  threaten her-as scared and pumped up on fear & adrenaline as I was, I meant every word.     That was the day I learned people really are that reckless and clueless about their own dogs.

There were 96 storage units over say 8 months at 20 apiece is $15360 swindled by thieves!!

Senator Wielochowski is right on in pointing out that the increase in production is primarily from Conoco projects in the planning stages for many years and started under ACES. Giving credit to SB21 is a sham. The producers are doing work they would have been doing anyway because they make one hell of a lot of money off the North Slope but now we are paying them to do 65% of that work. And even after so heavily subsidizing them we get back such a low(negative) return on our investment that for the first time in our history we are paying more to the oil industry than we get back in production taxes. And that will continue long into the future because of the "new oil" clause of SB21 that keeps production tax at 4% or lower. It was estimated at the time SB21 was being shoved out of the legislature that it would take a minimum of 90,000bbls/day to make up for the revenue lost to the bill. So an increase of 4,000 is nifty but nowhere near what is needed to refill the TAPS as was promised.

Bison also often know better than "planners" what their range needs are!  I recall when bison were moved from Delta to GMU 19.  Planners determined that the Windy Fork (of the Kuskokwim) was ideal habitat, so that is where the animals were placed.  The bison promptly moved over to the South Fork and up toward Post River where they happily grazed for many years.   When the Bear Creek Fire (1977) converted a lot of black spruce vegetation to grasses and sedges in the area of what is now commonly referred to as the Farewell Burn, the bison again moved and expanded their range in Unit 19.

I attended and thought it a very well run and informative  forum. We in the general public often end up voting for candidates we know little about, and who will be serving in jobs we also know little about. Forums like this help end the ignorance. 
Hugh Massengill, Eugene

The problem with medical insurance in general is that there is insufficient pressure on either providers or consumers to cut costs.  Doctors in Alaska are generally over-paid, and there is no incentive for them to cut their fees.  If there were a single payer system, the single health care payer would be able to bring cost containment pressure to bear on providers.  The other problem is that there is little incentive for consumers to cut costs if they aren't the ones paying - indeed, the pressure on them is to get the most expensive care possible in order to get the most mileage out of their deductibles, and because of the perception that expensive = better.  There needs to be a system in place to incentivize  comparison shopping and price containment for consumers, coupled with price transparency throughout the health care system.

20 years ago, when faced with the prospect of ever declining North Slope oil production, ARCO Alaska undertook a radical reorganization.  Major reductions were made in many departments, among them the Major Projects organization and Government and Public Affairs.  Layers of middle management disappeared. Total headcount went from about 2500 to about 1700.  Hundreds of jobs were re-graded.  No one took a pay cut.  But salaries were frozen until performance and years of service moved an employee up within their new, lower grade.  All of this was announced and implemented in a matter of a few months.  People weren't happy.  Some left the company because the career advancements achieved so far disappeared.  They found jobs elsewhere.  But most stayed.  And a year later, the new organization was functioning well and people had adjusted to a new reality.  Most were content to still be in Alaska doing jobs they loved.  U of A should consider this approach.

Most agree that the State is facing a financial crisis.  Tools to solve this problem are:
1)  Cutting expenses - This is being addressed and expenses have been reduced and will continue to be reduced.  However, achieving "billion dollar" expense reductions is unlikely.  Those who suggest this as the major component for solving the financial crisis have simply not looked at where the State spends money.  Nor have they identified which programs or services should be eliminated. 
2) Spending Reserves - Reserves could be used to close the gap this year but would do nothing to solve the underlying problem.  Next year the problem would only be bigger.  And this solution could result in a downgraded credit rating for the State which will increase State spending.
3) New Revenues -  The most obvious choices are restructuring the Permanent Fund to generate general fund revenue, increasing existing taxes, or imposing new taxes.  

Because of scale, the Permanent Fund must be part of the solution.

Wasn't that the point the law that the teenager championed? To prevent school districts from blaming parents when the districts fail to do their job?  The parents appear to have done their due diligence: They approached the school before enrolling their child; they sought help from school personnel and then district administrators; and, finally, they filed a complaint with the state department of ed.  Would you make this same accusation if the student couldn't attend school because she was in a wheelchair and there was no ramp? Clearly, she needed accommodations, including an IEP, and the district ignored her; how is that her parents' fault?

Are there any commenters who are going to call the supervisor on this obvious distortion? 

I think this email-leaking parent did exactly the right thing. If a teacher has been assigning something like this for 20 years, there's no point in "confronting her directly". If her supervisor comes up with the line that defends her free-range, earth-friendly snobbery was "a joke", there's no reason to talk to anyone at the school about this assignment (clearly the entire administration sees the mind-numbing cognitive dissonance in labeling a cake full of sugar "earth friendly" and "cruelty free"). Leak it to the WW, and see what happens: Lo and behold, suddenly the creativity-loving food snob changes her tune.

There's nothing wrong with advocating for creativity (though I personally am skeptical of elementary school creativity proselytizers). There's absolutely nothing wrong with using and advocating "earth friendly" and "human healthy" ingredients.  But a middle school teacher - even one who lives in Portland - has no credentials to know what these ingredients are, and no right to push parents of her students to make financial lifestyle decisions based on the teacher's personal moral stance on branding and labeling of chicken and wheat products. In any case, she's recommending they make cakes out of cookie or brownie or cake batters. The number 1 or 2 ingredient is going to be some form of sugar, which is probably the worst thing you could eat, health-wise, and "plantation-consciousness"-wise, anyway.

Follow the legal reasoning. Per the law, to use a firearm against another person, even just to threaten, is to use deadly force. Even if you don't actually fire, you have still used deadly force.

The use of deadly force in self-defense is only legally justified if the threat you are defending against is also a deadly force threat, armed or not. So, if you state you felt a deliberate shot to the leg (which can easily kill or maim regardless) was "sufficient" to stop a threat, almost by definition you did not feel that threat was actually serious enough to justify using the gun at all. If you didn't think the attack constituted a threat of death or grievous bodily harm, why were you shooting?

Firearms cannot, by law, be used as "less lethal" defensive weapons to ensure compliance or to counter non-lethal threats, regardless of your intent. If they aren't threatening your life, you don't even threaten with a gun, much less shoot. If they are, you shoot to stop, not to wound.

The school board might want to have its attorney brief them on City of Kenai v. Kenai Peninsula Newspapers (642 P.2d 1316 (1982)).

http://law.justia.com/cases/alaska/supreme-court/1982/4954-0.html

This decision by the Alaska Supreme Court combined cases in Kenai and Anchorage where the former tried to keep city manager applications from the public, and the latter tried to keep police chief applications from the public.  Newspapers, including the Anchorage Daily News, sued, and won.

The Court affirmed Superior Court decisions that: (a) concluded that applications were public records and that the deliberations of the Kenai city council concerning appointment of a city manager must be held in public meetings. The court thereupon ordered the city to permit the inspection and copying of the applications and to refrain from any closed deliberations concerning the selection of the new city manager.

(b) Public Records law trumped an Anchorage ordinance keeping applications confidential.

A surrogate is implanted with an embryo created by IVF. The resulting child is genetically unrelated to the surrogate. There are several sub-types of gestational surrogacy as noted below. ...

Ojan from PAX Labs here. We appreciate the shout-out!  I thought I'd chime with a few tips from our PAX Pros. First, I have to say disassembling your pods could cause them to leak into the device which would void the warranty. Just putting that out there.

For our PAX 2, it requires minimal cleaning compared to the original device - once per week at most, or twice a month depending on your usage - and no more mouthpiece lubricant (yay).

We suggest cycling through the 4 temp settings, 360f to 420f, as your session progresses so you get the most out of your loose-leaf. Also with lip sensing tech, a redesigned oven, and more efficient heating, a full charge can last 5-10 sessions depending on usage before needing to recharge via USB, or with our AC adapter.

And don't forget about our 10 year warranty, backed by the PAX Pro's.  We know it's an investment and will stand behind it.

Hope this was helpful. Cheers!

Is the dividend an entitlement? No. Is the dividend a safety net? No. It is a DIVIDEND people! A dividend is given to shareholders when there is money to give. Any mentions of "regressiveness" or "progressiveness" are simply code words for wealth redistribution. Should only rich people pay for government? Is that the idea? It took me 15 seconds on the internet to find that ITEP is a liberal think tank whose main idea is that everyone should pay an equal share (percentage) of their income for government. Elmer would not have supported such socialist claptrap. Article 9 Paragraph 6 of the Alaska Constitution states: "No tax shall be levied, or appropriation of public money made, or public property transferred, nor shall the public credit be used, except for a public purpose." So the idea of imposing an income tax while handing out dividend cash with no qualification (a public purpose) is patently unconstitutional. If you really want an income tax then reform the dividend first.

Collectively, every inmate, who ever did any time in Alaska's prison system, knows all the guards, their addresses, their family member's names, their dog's name.  Over the decades, I know of only one released prisoner, in Juneau, that went to a guards home, and shot their dog with a BB-gun.  And that was probably a direct result of his being released into the public, directly out of the hole, after spending almost 5 years straight, in the hole.  Most guards, upon meeting a former inmate on the streets, are greeted rather cordially, or at worse, simply ignored.  The vast majority of inmates recognize that they screwed up, and that their prison time was their own fault ... and if they were mistreated by any guard ... well, it came, unofficially, with the sentence.

The tax increases to the wealthy are relatively small, to be honest. In fact, Bernie's proposed brackets are almost identical the the tax levels that Reagan endorsed in the early 1980s, while running for President. Any income that comes in under the new bracket is taxed at the old levels; it's only the part of your income that exceeds the new bracket thresholds that will be taxed at new levels. So, for example, the first new bracket is $250,000/year. Everything from $249,999 and down will still be taxed at 33%; everything over will be taxed at the new 37% level. The entire set of changes are as follows:

$250,000+/year will be 37%.
$500,000+/year will be 43%.
$2,000,000+/year will be 48%.
$10,000,000+/year will be 52%

I would also point out that his proposed taxation levels, to accomplish all of this, are almost exactly the same as what Reagan repeatedly fought for.

Regardless of the merits of the Juneau road project, one fact sticks out.  DOT has consistently underestimated its costs, and has been very slow to update cost projections for construction and maintenance of the road.

First of all, the last DOT cost estimate for the project, which is already obsolete, was $574 million, not the $552 million in the op-ed.  $22 million may be chump change to some, but not to me.

Second, at one time during the project "planning," the cost of ferries dedicated to run between the end of the new road and Haines and Skagway were appropriately included in the project costs.  Then, when the Alaska Class ferry was initially designed to be able to serve the entire AMHS service area, the ferry costs were deleted. Then a re-design occurred, and the new ferries will be Juneau Access day boats only; their costs have never been added back to the project, however.

Bottom line: It is closer to a $1 billion project in today's dollars.

Some Corporations can't pass the costs on to the consumer because their consumers are not in Oregon.  Increasing their costs by 2.5% will make them unable to compete in the rest of the US or the world and they will either have to quit business or move.  Think RV manufacturing.  Most of it is now in the Midwest where it is central to raw materials and transportation.  If a Coburg or Harrisburg RV company has to charge 2.5% more than all those companies in Indiana, they lose.  Add in the transportation costs from Oregon to wherever and they really lose. If they are gone, local governments and school districts get no property tax money; and the State of Oregon gets no income tax money from their employees. It's not a matter of greed; it's a matter of economics.

This can be confusing because everyone seems to have their own point of reference. You are correct that Juneau clock time now is closely equal to solar time during winter (Alaska Standard Time). During the summer now (under Alaska Daylight Savings Time) Anchorage is 2 hours ahead and Juneau is 1 hour ahead from solar time. Under MacKinnon's bill this relationship would remain and Juneau would be on same clock time as the west coast in the winter (when the west coast "falls back") but be one hour ahead of solar time. Central Alaska would be 2 hours ahead of solar time year-round. Ironically, back when Southeast was on Pacific Time for "convenience" sake, they were 1 hour ahead of solar time in the winter and 2 hours ahead during Daylight savings time in the summer. There is actually only a 1 hour 2 minute difference in solar time between Juneau and Anchorage. I hope I didn't make this more confusing - LOL

He may also not realize that the decibel level and frequency has increased in the past 10 years, per Federal law changes.

In terms of taxpayer cost for the QZ, it's an important issue because it involves the fundamental livability of Eugene, and people literally lose sleep over the issue.  With a QZ in place, the whole city will benefit economically, and eventually the QZ will pay for itself through increased economic activity.  Lot of development has been put on hold because of excessive train noise.

Not sure where definitions are from.  The classic from the 1964 Act is of course, "untrammeled".  The reality is that over the past 3 decades, certain interest groups have used the public support of the original 1964 Act and the truly wild areas that were preserved to include more and more areas that are small and not "untrammeled" Areas with roads, previous timber harvests and other development have been annexed into the bevy of "Wilderness areas" over the years.  In the process it often means that existing users, recreationists such as mountain bikers have been shut out.
The reality is that nationally, use of wilderness areas either in absolute numbers or per capita has been declining since the late 1980's - demographics and urbanization.  Sure there a few spots in a few wilderness areas that continue to get heavily used, but most of it not.  Hence why the FS is not able to get more funding, no constituency raising heck about it.  Perhaps letting bikers in would help this.

It is impossible for  the Republicans to "Gerrymander" their 'way to control the Senate'.  

Control of the Senate depends on how many senators there are from each party nationwide.  Since the people of each state currently elect their two (2) Senators statewide, there are no lines within a State to 'gerrymander'.   Everybody in Oregon gets to vote on a Senator this year.

The House of Representatives is subject to gerrymandering, of course.  Every 10 years, whichever party has control of a State's legislature can re-draw internal voting boundaries to their party's advantage.   You have no vote on that subject, of course other than electing the state politicians who get to draw the lines for Oregon.

A sales tax with no exemptions is the only way it can be considered fair.

So how big of a sales tax would be required?  Juneau has a 5% sales tax and brings in $43 million spread across about 30,000 residents.  Expand that to the entire state and that brings in about $1 billion.  But it has a few problems:
1.  Juneau gets a million cruise tourists a year, so sales tax revenue is likely higher there than it would be elsewhere.  In reality the state sales tax would need to be 6% or more.
2.  Many out-of-state owned businesses skip town without remitting their taxes.  Difficult to enforce when the business is operating in the Virgin Islands or whatever winter cruise port.  It's a perennial problem there.
3.  A state sales tax would be piled on top of existing municipal sales taxes in the communities that have them (i.e. Juneau would have a 10% sales tax).  So they would have to switch to higher property taxes which the sales tax supporters would probably consider even less fair.

If you just gotta have a sales tax, make it a big one only in the summer season.

Gotta love this concept - let's dig ourselves out of the $4 billion fiscal hole by giving state residents $1.4 billion in a PFD. One third of the budget deficit is our desire to pay ourselves first before paying any of the bills. Of which $400 million goes to the Feds in taxes. 

Don't touch my PFD - what a great rallying cry, if we want to end up in bankruptcy as a state. 

How about we get a dividend if all the state expenses are balanced and paid for first, like normal dividends are calculated in the private sector. If we want to be adults and not kids in the candy store, let's be honest that we are the biggest line item expense in the state budget.  

It doesn't take a genius to figure out the quickest way to default as a state is to keep doling out large sums of money to residents. Funny how people will point out the failure of federal handouts, but think state handouts in the form of a PFD are just great. The Permanent Fund is constitutionally protected - the PFD is not.

Wiles was completely on-point when she said, "It's code for racial and economic segregation." One might assume that as school enrollment, course offerings, and test scores decrease, appropriate funding would be provided to resolve such issues; however, this is not reality. As schools suffer, funding dwindles, leading to further issues. 

Most low-income families from the NEHS area do not have the time, money, or resources to transfer their children to other schools, thus are limited in their options. Families with such resources however do, and they choose their schools accordingly. This ongoing cycle of economically secure families transferring their children away from NEHS leaves only families suffering from socio-economic disparity. We see the same cycle all over the US. It's social-choice segregation, which, in turn, leaves schools like NEHS underfunded, understaffed, with a greater population of lower-income student. School choice only goes to benefit families that can afford it.

What is crazy is to tie shootings with gun collectors. It is illegal to discharge a firearm inside the city except on a firing range or when necessity applies. Even then, it may be unwise or irresponsible to shoot (because most bullets miss the intended target but ALWAYS hit someone or something: if not the intended target, than an unintended one). Statistical evidence is that misconduct (or legal but unwise use) of firearms is almost never associated with collections - the typical collector’s piece is never discharged (and loses value if it is used and worn). The path to “put a dent in these shootings” surely lies in figuring out how to deter or prevent them in the first place? My suggestion is to advocate both civic and firearms education. Spread the ethic that to call the police AND disclose ALL you know is the BEST path to a civil community. And certainly advocate that anyone who is armed learn about “fire discipline and fire control.”

Re: Gender identity and discrimination. Basically I agree with Thomas Morse that some religions aggravate discrimination and it is wrong to do so. However, I would raise an issue regarding the clarity of how it is determined that "you is or you aint" in any given category. As with cataloguing any trait (religious belief, interest in fishing, or even sexual identification) characteristics are seldom YES or NO. Rather, reality presents a wide continuum of incremental differences - which might even change over time for one individual.

Apparatus at birth can be misleading. Shifts in sexual orientation might possibly be genetic, hormonal, medical, or even arising from educational or philosophical changes. Perhaps there are actually lesser or greater variations of bi-sexuality which permeate all human beings, but which are currently not measured. Humans travel the world and have extensive genetic mixing - as different from the more closed populations of other animals. (continued next post)

How is it that military families continue to get all the perks when the military family member dies, but not law enforcement? Why is it that people get on their knees & bow to military, but not law enforcement & firefighters? I'm the spouse of a military member.  I have since divorced, but when married I thought all the benefits of being military were great. The base pay was low, but all the additional dollars you receive to cover rent & food & the free medical care all add up to being better than many civilians. The AF also paid some of my tuition for school. My spouse along with many other military members joined the military not for a sense of patriotism, but for the benefits education & money. I'm not saying they don't deserve perks for being willing to serve, but law enforcement & firefighters also put their lives on the line. The families of these brave law enforcement & firefighters should at least have access to benefits until they die or remarry or get their own insurance!

I find that a lot of people make converse errors in their presentations, which leads to the offense. 

In formal logic, a converse error is taking the general argument "A implies B" and assuming "B implies A".

How this works in practice is turning "terrorists are primarily Muslim" into "Muslims are primarily terrorists". One of these statements is true and inoffensive, the other false and offensive.

In 1976, voters were asked if they thought the legislature should put a proposition on a future ballot if the voters should "advise" the state legislature to adopt a unicameral legislature. 

Yes: 58,782 (51.6%) Approved
No: 55,204 (48.4%)

"The vote on this proposition does not amend the state constitution. The question merely asks for an ADVISORY vote on whether the legislature should adopt a resolution placing before the qualified voters of the State at the next general election an amendment to the constitution of the State providing for a unicameral legislature.
  
The POSITIVE VOTE on this advisory measure DID NOT INSPIRE the Alaska State Legislature to place the requested constitutional amendment on the ballot. 

I bet this would now be AT LEAST a 55% YES VOTE and probably closer to 60% and once again the legislature would probably thumb noses at it. However this time the language should read by replacing the word "advise" with "require".

In October 2005, Congress passed and President Bush signed into law legislation making it unlawful for any licensed importer, manufacturer or dealer to sell or transfer any handgun unless the transferee is provided with a secure gun storage or safety device. A “secure gun storage or safety device” is defined in 18 U.S.C. § 921(a)(34) as: (A) a device that, when installed on a firearm, is designed to prevent the firearm from being operated without first deactivating the device; (B) a device incorporated into the design of the firearm that is designed to prevent the operation of the firearm by anyone not having access to the device; or C) a safe, gun safe, gun case, lock box, or other device that is designed to be or can be used to store a firearm and that is designed to be unlocked only by means of a key, a combination, or other similar means. The "methane boils out of the tundra and cooks the earth" meme was debunked in 2011 by the U.S.G.S.  Two lines of evidence:  One was a numerical simulation that failed to demonstrate runaway hydrate melting (Live by the Computer Model; Fall by the Computer Model); the second is observation of the geologic/ice core record that fails to show any huge methane spikes or wholesale permafrost melting in any of the (numerous) interglacials we've had previously, that were just as warm as anything predicted for the rest of the 21st Century.  See this reference:  Ruppel, C. D. (2011), "Methane Hydrates and Contemporary Climate Change", in _Nature Education Knowledge_ 3(10):29.

Being at Columbia University in physics in the 70's, I have to take issue with Isenberg's history.  There was little doubt in physicist's minds in the 1970's about black holes.  Without even getting into general relativity, it was clear that a suitably massive star simply could not by any known force avoid collapse to a singularity when no longer able to generate fusion power.  Also, Newton was essentially silent on gravity waves dealing rather with relatively stationary bodies.  If Isenberg had asked Newton what would happen if the sun were displaced by million miles in 10 seconds, I suspect Newton would have paused and speculated on a gravitational field distortion at large distances from the Sun that resembles gravitational waves.  Of course, we cannot ask Newton, but the point is that the analogy between the emission of electromagnetic (light) and gravitational waves is not so incredibly different.

Discarding Isenberg's history, of course detection of gravity waves is important.

You can hunt moose with a permit and small game by archery, .22 rifle, shotgun, and falconry in the Skilak Loop Management Area.  The Cooper Landing Closed Area is closed only to the taking of Dall sheep and mountain goats.  You can hunt moose, black bears, brown bears, Dall sheep, mountain goats, and small game in Chugach State Park.  Got any others?

The full-curl restrictions on Dall sheep hunting and antler restrictions for moose hunting are not intended to allocate animals among user groups.  They are to keep hunters from shooting too many sheep and moose while avoiding restrictions on the number of hunters (by permits) or extremely short hunting seasons.

The law forbids any kind of possession by anyone other than the owner, other than the exceptions that I mentioned earlier for target shooting, hunting, and getting gunsmithing done.   The Oregon Firearms Safety Act of 2015 is quite strict.  If you say loaned a gun to a friend or relative for them to have for protection, that is now very much illegal to do.    Guns can only be loaned for hunting and target shooting, and have to be returned to the owner once the hunt or target shooting is done.

It is not just a matter of change of ownership.   The law very much restricts change of possession too.

Take a look at the law yourself.  If you can find something in it that would indicate that this would be legal, do let me know.   For I certainly cannot find anything in the new law that would allow for something like what happened in this incident to be legal.

As I said before, this seems to me to be a case of prosecutorial discretion.   And that is legal for prosecutors to do.

QUOTE: "There are two other methods for the federal government to acquire legislative jurisdiction over land within a State. It should be noted that neither of these are found in the Constitution. They are judicially created methods. The first is for the States to pass a general cession statute. ... The second method is for the federal government to reserve jurisdiction at the time statehood is granted to a territory. This does not involve a transfer of legislative jurisdiction because the State never had jurisdiction over the land in the first place. This is how the federal government gained control over so much property in the western United States."

With that in mind, ponder the information in the following link: http://www.backcountrychronicles.com/public-hunting-land/

The chart at that link should make every thinking Oregonian weep, and then get angry!

For some reason I seem to be David Brooks' antimatter to his matter. I read his columns and most of his points just kind of get wispy for me.

I sift through this column and find little real substance. 
Hugh Massengill, Eugene

By voting against the school bonds, I hope the city and school district get one message, that is, you should not bond for items that are maintenance.  When you build a school, you may construct it to last 50 years, but there are certain things that will need to be replaced well before the 50 year life ends.  Boilers, roofs etc.  These items should be budgeted for through the use of a sinking fund, not a bond.  Each year there should be a portion of the ASD operating budget set aside for building repair and maintenance and when the time comes to repair or replace a boiler or roof, the money is there.  Rather than pay interest on a bond, you could actually earn interest through investing the set aside in safe holding accounts.  The only time bonds should be used is to construct a new facility, add on to an existing, or perform a major renovation that will substantially increase the expected life of the facility.

"People are not going to stop moving to Portland, so the big question is how to meed demand."

Statements like this exemplify a glaring blind spot in so much free-market-fundamentalist thinking and discussion about Portland's housing crisis.  

It's simply not true that the only control citizens have over the problems of immigration and housing are "supply" and "demand," and that all else is decided by the unregulable, un-blame-able marketplace.  Our current growth rate, good or bad, is the result of concerted effort by our elected officials and planners.  As it turns out, they benefit from growth a lot more than the rest of us.

What, where and how much Portland chooses to grow has a tremendous effect on how many people move here and who they are.  The vast majority of Portlanders are deeply alienated by the current rate of change, and that's not a problem we can solve by building faster.  There are other, better solutions to this crisis.  Maybe WWeek should look into that.

The ban on the using 'braves' leaves me with mixed feelings.   I does help keep our native american tribes images alive in some ways.   The question would be if it means anything at all as a reflection of their culture?   For the most part it is Indians as see through European eyes.      

Banning a school mascot seems an attempt to expunge our guilt by doing something symbolic, while leaving the reality that we have never really managed to keep 'separate but equal' status for most of the tribes in our nation.  Casino money alone has not addressed the many social stresses on these communities.

The fact that the tribes refused to endorse the 'Braves' is plenty of reason for me to ban the name.   If there is an offense, it will be felt by them, not those of European decent.  For the tribes it's not a liberal/conservative/democrat/republican issue.   It's their lives, it's their self image as  culture.   We should respect that.

I grew up in Michigan.  We could not swim in rivers or lakes due to industrial pollution (which since has been ended and one CAN swim today).  We passed a simple law which helped a great deal.  Industry must put put water in upstream of where they take it out.  The water must be more pure than when they took it. And NO storage of toxic material is permitted in any place where it could be leached by groundwater, because ground water eventually ends up in the Great Lakes (which are thought to be the largest freshwater reserve in the world).  My problem with these new Alaska mine projects is that they do not actually plan to deal with toxins properly (no doubt due to cost).  It is only worth mining IF you can afford to secure or clean up the mess as part of the deal, IMHO.  I favor development, if but only if you include full cleanup in the plan.

The "millions" of salmon left unexploited are pinks and chums, which processors don't want during the sockeye salmon season.

Today the use, sale and possession of cannabis (marijuana) in the United States remains illegal under federal law. However, some states have created exemptions for various uses, mainly medical. In four states, Alaska, Colorado, Oregon and Washington, the sale and possession of marijuana is legal for both medical and non-medical use; and Washington DC has legalized personal use but not commercial sale.[2] Multiple efforts to reschedule cannabis under the Controlled Substances Act have failed, and the United States Supreme Court has ruled in United States v. Oakland Cannabis Buyers' Cooperative and Gonzales v. Raich that the federal government has a right to regulate and criminalize cannabis, whether medical or recreational.

TimBerry,
I think you've got a couple things wrong. "...the court was brilliantly conceived to interpret the text to keep up with changes," and "the constitution allowed slavery and only male property holders could vote."
In both examples, the changes were effected via amendments; the 13th prohibited slavery and the 19th provided universal suffrage. No "interpretation" on the part of any court was needed.
In my opinion, constitutional interpretation is a slippery slope. After all, anyone, including a judge, can interpret any constitutional clause any way he or she wants even if totally detached from logic and reality. (Perhaps we've seen this?)
Rather, Judge Scalia's tenets of texturalism and originalism are what's needed; close adherence to the original meaning and intent of the Constitution. If it's clauses are no longer relevant and do not serve our nation, the proper and more difficult course is to amend the Constitution rather than take the less difficult path of interpretation.

"The village [Newtok] convened an ad hoc group of agencies and nonprofits to address the issues. Construction at the new village site began, and several houses and some infrastructure were completed. But tremendous hurdles remain."

There is basically one "tremendous hurdle': Money. If the people of Newtok had unlimited funds to move the whole village - at what, $1-2 million, per family - problem solved. But they don't, we don't, the agencies don't, and I'm dubious about the nonprofits. Unfortunately, Newtok has squandered much of the federal money that it has received, and has little to show for it. Check out the war between the old and new tribal councils, and where the money went.

Of course they want "their" village. But that means a huge new infrastructure for population of a few hundred people, when Toksook Bay, a few miles further, already has that infrastructure. Help folks to move where an economy of scale makes sense, and their needs, if not necessarily their wants, are met.
This alone should solve Alaska's economic conundrum! Money everywhere and 2% more smarter kids.
