Absolutely agree Christina! Our son's transition from elementary to middle school was very difficult because there was almost no information available to us.  We asked questions about programs and were told the information didn't exist, that it didn't matter anyway because an administrator downtown would decide where he would go to middle school.  I found that so shocking at the time, that we as his parents or even his school team had no say on which middle school he would attend.  When I asked why this person wasn't at the table I was told there was no choice but to "trust the process" which included NO information about the programs or schools he could attend.  It is really a shame that the more needs a child has, the less information information there is.  It makes no sense why this information can't be available to all parents with children in special education.  Parents need to be fully informed members of their child's IEP team to make informed choices.  This is an equity issue.

1.  The oil pipeline was paid for decades ago.

The secrecy of all this must be changed, too, so Alaskans can be better informed about the magnitude of the theft of our finite resources.

I feel compelled to comment on this, being a parent of a 19 year old boy. We have traveled with him to Europe and Asia where there are no legal drinking ages for consumption (not sure what the legal age is for purchase in France). We realize he drinks at least some alcohol when his is with his college buddies. When we are home together, we offer a small amount of whatever we are drinking with dinner (beer or wine) to model good social drinking behavior. We have zero tolerance for drinking and driving (even a small amount) and we have discussions about the difference between social drinking and binge drinking. Every family should examine their own behavior around alcohol, assess their own child and then decide what makes sense. Personally I would never "bring the party home" because that promotes binge drinking, which is extremely dangerous.

It isn't because of Obamacare; it is because of the rapacious insurance and pharmaceutical industries. You're right about your situation and  many others (even those of us with employer-subsidized plans are suddenly in trouble). It's why we need to cripple the insurance industry in this country; remove the parasites from coverage of our care. There's a bit of difference between the devices you suggest and a gun in terms of risk mitigation. 
A seatbelt is a risk mitigation device. It does nothing to prevent an accident. It reduces the risk of harm due to the accident. Wearing or not wearing a seatbelt does not alter the underlying risk or make me more prone to accident 

Locking my door does not prevent a robbery. It serves to prevent a specific type of robbery - but does not prevent all robberies. 

Can you point to any other situation where the device used to mitigate the risk is directly tied to or source of the risk? We don't mitigate the risk of an oil spill by spilling oil. We don't mitigate the risk of a car crash by crashing a car. Yet we encourage people to mitigate possible instances of violence, often perpetrated with guns, by carrying that same device as the mitigator?

The archetypal definition of the word ‘liberal’ via Webster’s An American Dictionary of the English Language, 1853 - 1st publication 1828 Part 1

LIB'ER-AL, a. [Fr., from L. liberalis, from liber, free. see Libel.] 
1. Of a FREE heart; FREE to give or bestow; not close or contracted; munificent; bountiful; generous; giving largely; as, a liberal donor; the liberal founders of a college or hospital. It expresses less than Profuse or Extravagant. 2. Generous; ample; large; as, a liberal donation; a liberal allowance. 3. Not selfish, narrow, or contracted; catholic; enlarged; embracing other interests than one's own; as, liberal sentiments or views; a liberal mind; liberal policy. 4. General; extensive; embracing literature and the sciences generally; as, a liberal education. This phrase is often, but not necessarily, synonymous with COLLEGIATE; as, a collegiate education. 5. FREE; open; candid; as, a liberal communication of thoughts.

One reason employers offer benefits is to entice people to come to work at their business.  If the State wants the best lawyers for its judges, it needs to offer some incentive for them to switch from their current practice.  These aren't secretaries or snow plow operators, but instead highly trained and successful lawyers who have much better options.  Even though the salary of a judge is quite high (around 170k), that still often represents a pay cut for the people who are most qualified for the position.  So, the State needs to offer something else.  The strong retirement is a good incentive, especially considering the person has to leave a job where they have been building up their retirement in order to be a judge.  

In the end, you get what you pay for.  Cutting the incentives would result in less qualified judges.

To the contrary, Justice Blackmun quoted it to justify that the constitutional right to abortion isn't unlimited.
In the 1996 case of Fieger v. Thomas, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit both recognized and criticized Buck v. Bell by writing "as Justice Holmes pointed out in the only part of Buck v. Bell that remains unrepudiated, a claim of a violation of the Equal Protection Clause based upon selective enforcement 'is the usual last resort of constitutional arguments.'" In 2001, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit cited Buck v. Bell to protect the constitutional rights of a woman coerced into sterilization without procedural due process. The court stated that error and abuse will result if the State does not follow the procedural requirements, established by Buck v. Bell, for performing an involuntary sterilization.

The solution is simple. Have one reinsurance pool common to all Alaska health insurance providers, whether they operate in the group or individual market. All Alaska health insurance providers would both pay into the fund and be reimbursed from it for catastrophic claims.

If I read Senate Bill 206 correctly, it keeps the ACHIA alive as a stand alone insurance provider of last resort. I don't understand why we would continue to spend money doing this, as nobody can be denied coverage now under the PPACA. There are Federal subsidies for many families available when purchasing plans through the marketplace, but not when purchasing a plan under ACHIA. Perhaps I'm missing something, but why would those formerly uninsurables choose an expensive ACHIA plan with limited benefits instead? It makes no sense to me.

Downsize the ACHIA and make it a simple, common statewide catastrophic claim reinsurance pool across both the group and individual markets. Keep it simple.

There is a very simple solution that would allow non-consumptive users to contribute to state sponsored wildlife education, conservation, and wildlife viewing programs and that is to have a voluntary checkoff on the PFD application. If this were in place, one could contribute as much as one wants from one's PFD. 

But there is a catch, as a non-consumptive user - I would want equal representation on the Board of Game as opposed to the second class status that non-consumptive users currently are relegated to. It is for this reason that while the hunting community may complain about non-hunters not contributing financially, in reality, this is exactly what they want as it helps them to maintain their political monopoly on fish and wildlife resources. 

During a time when the state is facing a serious budget crunch, such a proposal as the above, only makes sense to help fund the above programs regardless of opposition from the hunting community.

Every abortion drama has three main characters (the mother, the father, and the child) and a host of supporting characters (doctors, nurses, grandparents, friends, etc.). 

No abortion drama is ever rightly lived out unless all three of its main characters are treated positively in a meaningful way. How many times is that done now? The answer to that question is: Almost never. Instead, the mother is made victim, the father is scorned as scum, and the child is discarded as something worthless that never happened. Consequently, loving relationships are destroyed, and lifelong angers and regrets take root in their ashes.  That is the status quo, and that does not work.

My proposal treats all three of an abortion drama's main characters with dignity and respect.  The mother controls her body and her destiny, the father publicly accepts responsibility for his part in the pregnancy, and the child gets a name and therefore becomes a human being who is also a person in the eyes of the law.

A critical thinking textbook might categorize this post as an example of sweeping generalization. That aside, I would argue that all fields of knowledge have an ideology, though many strive to render it natural or invisible. Subject matter, epistemology, and ideology join hands to the extent that a branch of knowledge focuses on certain questions, enacts characteristic forms of inquiry and ways of knowing that produce certain kinds of beliefs. For example, a field of knowledge like natural science that many would say is fact not ideology embraces a materialist epistemology that runs counter to a spiritualist or religious epistemology. One sees truth revealed in an objective world from a process of observation and experiment. The other sees truth revealed from a divine source recorded in sacred texts by prophets. Individuals can hold multiple views and work within many knowledge systems. Have you explored your own ideology/worldview? Might explain why you feel antagonized by education.

Erhm, but there *has* been competition.  Electric cars, for example, were pioneered at the turn of the century - the 20th C.  Problem was, they couldn't compete with the IC engine.  Could we, and should we, move forward to new technologies when we can?  Of course, and by and large we are doing exactly that.  However, in the meantime let's keep the lights turned on and the wheels turning, else the "solution" that we're promoting may end up creating more dearth, deprivation, and (yes) death than the "problem" we're trying to solve.

I'm cautiously optimistic that the IC engine may be phased out in coming years as fuel-cell tech matures.  We'll see.  And - who knows?  30 years from now we may hop in our sleek electric sedans and cruise down the pike, powered by induction coils buried in the roadbed.  And this won't seem any more remarkable than the fact that our roads today are paved with asphalt or concrete.

"Goldilocks and the Three Bears" and the older "The Story of the Three Bears" are two variations of an old fairy tale. The original tale tells of an ugly, old woman who enters the forest home of three bachelor bears whilst they are away. She sits in their chairs, eats some of their porridge, and falls asleep in one of their beds. When the bears return and discover her, she starts up, jumps from the window, and is never seen again. The other major version brings Goldilocks to the tale (replacing the old woman), and an even later version retained Goldilocks, but has the three bachelor bears transformed into Papa, Mama, and Baby Bear...

Daddy Bear, moves, like Momma Bear. The most ferocious animal on a local plant.

The cruise industry is important to Alaska.  The 1 million passengers they bring annually travel throughout the state, stay at our hotels (including mine), eat at our restaurants, pay taxes and provide jobs.  The Alaska Visitor industry alone has 46,000 jobs with a 78% resident hire and an economic impact to our state of $3.9 Billion.  The cruise lines are not opposed to paying a passenger entry fee tax, they are opposed to having this tax spent on projects that don't provide a direct benefit to the passengers paying for those projects.  Juneau's $10 million artificial island and whale sculpture won't be seen by anyone in the downtown core.  It's continued maintenance and operational costs will be paid by whom - CBJ operating funds or continued misuse of passenger entry fee taxes?  Juneau is a great port for the cruise lines - they just want the fees their guests pay to visit Juneau to be used in a responsible and legal way.

This "reporting" is horrid. Allow me to correct some of the glaring errors. First of all, the RRQZ advisory committee has mostly business interests represented, and most of those are from downtown, where only three crossings exist. There were also usually five to seven city staff members participating.

Secondly, the panel did not recommend the reconfiguration of the easternmost crossing. That was apparently a requirement from City Council, though I am taking city staff's word for that part (they may have created this "requirement" out of thin air). That reconfiguration is what is forcing the closure of a crossing since railroads are allowed to force crossings to close when they allow a new one to be built. 

Third, there was no final recommendation that the crossing that is closed be Lawrence.

I would add that the majority of the people who live near the crossings, the Whiteaker residents, do not find the horns to be particularly bothersome, by all accounts. Yes, I live there.

USO is an ETF that attempts to track the cost of WTI oil.  It's mostly geared for people who want to short term trade the movements in oil.  You would be better served looking at the actually price of a barrel of oil (approx. $34.30).  The price of oil fell from ~$147/barrel to ~$30 in 2008.  The cost of gasoline subsequently fell into the $1.xx range.  Oil then rebounded to around $110/barrel, and has subsequently fallen back to the $30 range.  The cost of gasoline is once again back in the $1.xx range.  

Oil is only one input cost for other goods and services.  Another factor to keep in mind is inflationary monetary policy.  M2 money supply has nearly doubled since 2008.  This is the biggest reason for the increase in the cost of living.  As you point out, the cost of everything is going "up up and up."  This of course is happening in a time when there allegedly is no inflation.  The answer for that is that government CPI methods don't accurately capture inflation.

I always find the Star Wars/Star Trek debate funny because they seem so different to me that I have a hard time understanding how the two can be compared. Star Trek was created as a series of books and an episodic TV show, meaning that it was meant to have discreet stories told and wrapped up in a short time. Star Wars, on the other hand, was written as a series of movies with a far-reaching storyline. Star Trek is meant to be set in our own future, complete with our history and built upon our understanding of the real universe. Star Wars, however, exists "a long time ago, in a galaxy far, far away." That opens SW up to potentially involve elements that would be too fantastical in a universe based on our own, no matter how futuristic. There are many other reasons, but fundamentally, comparing SW and ST does not seem like an appropriate comparison. (Also, if you insist on comparing them, it would probably be best to be done by someone with a reasonable degree of knowledge of both properties.)

Richard Corbeil might be interested to learn (if he's open to learning) that ALL long-distance phone calls within, to and from Alaska are subsidized per the federal Universal Service Fund law that requires "equalization" of rates.  Were our calls not equalized, none of us--even in Anchorage--could afford to call family members or merchants Outside.  

Densely-populated urban areas in the contiguous U.S. cost much less to serve with phone or internet than, say, the sparsely-populated Navajo reservation in Arizona.  The same principal, equalization, drives the Alaska internet program, and, BTW, by-pass mail.  And it's no news that Alaska receives FAR more in federal transportation funds than we Alaskans pay in federal taxes.    

So, some who trumpet, "Let them pay for what they use" might be chagrined to learn that they, too, suck the teet.  Little in today's world is as simple as it seems.  Truly understanding how government--or, for that matter, society--works takes more than bluster.

One should think though, that a business should be able to pay its own bills and not rely on state or federal government to pay for internet service. You do realize that through special programs and cooperation with providers like GCI, millions -- yes millions -- were spent to bring communication infrastructure to rural Alaska communities. So the connection is there but everyone else in Alaska should not be on the hook to pay the monthly service fees for internet.  You choose to live in that community. If it's too expensive, you have the freedom to move. Where there's a will there's a way. If I live to Florida and complain I'm too far to visit family in Seattle, that's my own problem, not a state government problem.  Life is all about choices and from your last rant about how often you get out of Unalaska, that is no one one's fault or responsibility but your own. You made that your home, deal with it or move. Be an adult and if it's hurting you financially, do something about it.

If, in my letter, I indicated that I agree with or believe the 2100 projections to be accurate, that would be an error on my part. I really don't know what to think or believe in the case of global warming. The fact that the majority of the scientist engaged in this and allied disciplines agree that mankind is a significant contributor to global warming, and what its projected effects will be, doesn't necessarily mean they're correct. There was a time not too long ago when the best medical practitioners, persons of science, didn't believe that blood circulated in the human body. The point being that there is always room for doubt.
The main point of my letter was that if sea levels begin to rise to the point where they begin to approach the 2100 predictions, it will happen slowly enough to allow people to adapt. This comment and PeterLoewy's comment point to a tension in Bryant's case. On the one hand, this is religious humanism. All people should have their dignity protected. The poor and homeless and suffering should be cared for. Period. Religious humanism makes this claim regardless of whether the recipients of our care respond the way we predict they will or the way we hope that they will. Human dignity should be protected, and we should be indefatigable in our efforts. 

Mixed into Bryant's case, though, are arguments that it is economically rational for us to pay more to house the poor and that we can predict the outcomes of making this investment and that we will in fact all benefit economically from the deal--within some foreseeable time frame. 

It is easy to see why Bryant wants to bring these arguments together; he wants to appeal to the largest possible number of people, from religious humanists to technocrats. But the arguments are distinct.

Awhile back SF invested millions in homeless services, transitional and long term housing, mental health and addiction counseling, health care, dental care, job skills training, placement and ongoing support, legal aid, case management, veterans services, access to computers and phones, every possible public benefit. After five years they studied how it all worked. What they found was very discouraging: the majority of homeless they served moved into the housing and used the services, but did not give up the street life. The transitional housing became occupied permanently by formerly undomiciled people who never became self supporting; never transitioned to somewhere more stable. They went home to their new apartments when they wanted to shower and sleep, went to the free Doctor or dentist when needed, but mostly they continued to spend all of their time back on the streets. It seems like we need to rethink our assumptions about what's needed and what works.

A transgender person is one whose gender identity does not conform to expectations based on their assigned sex, and assigned sex is exactly that: how the delivering doctor described you based on inspection.  Some transgender persons do wish to undergo gender-affirmation surgery, some don't.  Gender identity is not a binary thing.  It's our culture that is set up that way, and conformance to gender stereotype is pretty much expected.  Also, gender-affirmation surgery is quite expensive, and until recently - and only if you have a job with great benefits - covered by insurance.  So the most that many transgender folks who want to transition can practically do is hormone treatments and of course social transition - presenting according to their gender identity. Hence the freakout.

Boozer Schmidt has an interesting commentary about freedoms to work, worth reading and considering.  The real issue is not the actual dollars, but the purchasing power.  In 1968 the minimum wage was raised to  $1.60, vs. $1.00 in early 1967.  In terms of current purchasing power, the value of that $1.60 wage would now be equal to $10.34.   Historically, that is 1968 minimum wage level was the highest ever, in terms of its actual purchasing power.  However, here's the point, and the record is clear: quite soon after the minimum wage is raised, there's an immediate surge in inflation, which works to erode the increase in purchasing power, even totally negate that bump in the dollar wage.  Economists can make a pretty good case that the huge inflation rates we began to see in the early 1970s were triggered by that 1968 bump in the minimum wage.  Inflation is a great enemy of wage earners.  It destroys purchasing power.  Meanwhile, the "Big Boys" get to use price increases, and be ahead.

Rent or Own?  Note to individuals under 40...it is far cheaper in the long run to own and not rent. If you are able it's all about planning and focus. Long story short,  bought first home at 32 with small loan 10k  plus mortgage in 1973. Kept home, paid loan off early, sold it after 20 years and built new home. Sale plus savings allowed for new construction and no mortgage. Average cost per month to own my home, taxes plus home insurance 6,400,  utilities about 2,000 or $700 per month for 3 bedroom, 2.5 bath, 2500 square feet, 3 car garage. How much would it cost to rent a house with those spec's?...??, guessing about 1500 to 2,000 per month. So, planning plus not taking on unnecessary debt can result in the last 30 plus years of your life living way under the cost of renting - be it a house or most any apartment - tis really cheaper to own then rent and the bonus of discretionary funds for travel and toys.

Up until that point Apoyemos raised money for text books, supplies and for scholarships for the 8th grade trip - just like PTA, Boosters, etc raise money for supplies, clubs, sports trips etc.  It's certainly a discussion to have whether all that fund raising should be subject to the 1/3rd re-distribution that the foundations contribute to "All Hands Rasied." SW might point out that a series of recurrent major droughts in the 10th and 11th centuries CE seemed to have taken down the Classic Maya civilization.  A bit later, a similar climatic pattern in North America probably whacked the proto-urban Anasazi culture and their contemporaries in the American southwest in the 12th - 13th centuries.  

Such things can and do happen on long-term time scales on this variable ol' planet of ours, and SW is correct to suggest that a prudent society would take steps to deal with them.  While I agree with SW on that point, I don't agree that the solution is all of us going back to live like the Amish.  (I rather like 21st C. tech, don't you?)   :)  And, having lived in Arizona for a few years (where it is d****d hot in summer), I know that agriculture certainly is not only possible, but profitable, under higher temperatures than we have in Oregon.

Build a pipeline to bring in Canadian lakewater instead of tar sands oil, for starters.  Problem solved.

Here you go Mike. 
John Galt  is a character in Ayn Rand's novel Atlas Shrugged (1957). Although he is not identified by name until the last third of the novel, he is the object of its often-repeated question "Who is John Galt?" and of the quest to discover the answer.

As the plot unfolds, Galt is acknowledged to be a philosopher and inventor; he believes in the power and glory of the human mind, and the right of the individual to use his/her mind solely for him/herself. I see people texting (the rapid switch of focus from the crotch to what's going on in front of them and back again), people making other than hands-free calls on their cell phones, people busting through intersections on lights already turned red, and all manner of other dangerous infractions.
I suspect the reason it's as prevalent as I perceive it to be is that there are no consequences; no enforcement. In my opinion, lack of enforcement leads to lawlessness; specifically unsafe conditions on our public roads because people know the odds of getting away with violations are really good.

With physical mobility, the extended family has been scattered across our vast nation.  Most Grandchildren see their Grandparents once or twice a year (after all they may live thousands of miles away) and, on the flip side, most Grandparents get to spend little time with their Grandchildren.  We no longer have a functioning multi-generational lifestyle.  Kids and parents, then, when they "leave home", it usually Kids (young men and women) spending their time with their "age" peers.  Young people don't have the opportunity to both "give and receive" from Grandparents.  Those who do are the fortunate exceptions.  

The larger our metropolitan areas become and the further removed young people become from their families, the less we see of that important intergenerational contact

One huge caveat to the above letter worth noting: "mixing zones," the "dilution-solution."  Within mixing zones in Tier 2 waters, which can be quite large, polluters routinely ask for and receive waivers from DEC from the water quality criteria, the foundation of our water quality standards.  Chronic and acute toxicity are allowed, with the presumption that the rest of the waterbody will be able to maintain the public's "use" of the water.  DEC rarely if ever monitors the edge of the mz to see if the modeling was correct as to where criteria are eventually being met, rarely if ever monitors biota to see if there has been an impact, and rarely if ever has the pre-discharge data needed to know whether a change has occurred after the mz authorization.  

That's why having a viable mechanism for designating Tier 3 waters, with no mz, is so important.  As long as DEC can authorize mz, the public needs to be able to say certain waters are simply too important to be polluted and degraded.

6 year old statistics can be topped by more current research and this information proves the point about what BMI is intended for...  A population group,  not individuals.  

Does obesity lead to health problems? Yes,  we know that.  Is it that cut and dry? No,  it's not.  More and more research is showing someone can carry "above optimal" weight or have a "high" BMI and still be a fit,  healthy person.  I consider myself an example of that.  I used to carry an additional 110lb from what I do now.  I've kept it off for about 10 years.  My BMI is "overweight",  almost "obese".  My body fat percent is 22%.  For females 25-29% is considered medically acceptable while 21-24% is considered fitness level.  If I let the scale and BMI determine my fitness or health or predict my future that would be silly! It's much more complex than that.

Fish Forensic Science. So how do you identify what species another fish was praying on by looking at it's stomach contents? Lots of fish skeletons of different species are very similar in appearance and most of the soft tissues might be pretty much digested. Well every fish has a couple of bones that are thicker and tougher than most and remain in a fishes stomach longer too. These are the two otoliths, more commonly called ear bones, located on either side of the fishes head. Every fish has them and the every species has a different shape of otolith. They are usually only 2 or 3 millimeters wide in Alaska fish and they grow as the fish does and gets growth rings so they can be used to tell the fishes age. They can also tell us what humans were catching by locating them at archeological sites. I illustrated the guidebook... Believe it or not.

I fully get your point.  Balance to you means folks that are not consumptive users of game.  Yet you assume that the board of game controls the entire F&G budget and gets all the money.  It does not.  Those funds are disbursed throughout their budget for other things like habitat restoration, research, shooting ranges, etc., many things that have nothing to do with the Board of Game.  So your point is invalid.  If you want to have a voice in how shooters funds are used, feel free to call F&G, or your local Advisory Council.

But make no mistake, the reason that F&G does get those matching funds is directly due to the fact that they have to match those funds with hunting and fishing license fees and those hunting and fishing fees must stay within F&G.  So you can whine all you want about shooters, but the fact is those funds come to F&G due to hunters and fishermen, yet help shooters, boaters, viewers, and campers as well.

Fighting global warming does involve hardship.  By accepting higher rates to run the biomass plant, probably some fossil fuel is saved since more hydro power can be sent to California or elsewhere so as displace coal or natural gas power usage.

Fighting global warming is going to cost bundles.  Those serious about it will have to swallow many cost increases to be involved.

I don't believe a building of the size proposed can be made "quake proof". Buildings are designed to withstand a certain level of earthquake as expressed in the Richter scale. Each level increase from say 7 to 8 represents a 10 fold increase in energy. I would hope the City Council will debate the value of the extra cost for extra protection, not as the editorial implies, debating survivability versus immunity.

This article may give the impression that Rasmuson Foundation is in disagreement of Governor Walker’s efforts to address the state budget gap. To the contrary, we applaud his boldness in coming forward with a comprehensive plan featuring a combination of budget cuts, new revenues and using some reserves. We also applaud the legislature for making the budget the focus in the last days of the session.

As a Foundation working to improve the quality of life in Alaska, we hope the plan that is adopted is equitable in what it demands from Alaskans and puts the State on a path to long-term sustainability. According to this research, if only a portion of the Governor’s plan is adopted – budget cuts and Permanent Fund changes – without new revenues, the impact will fall mostly on middle-income working families and the poor, and barely, if at all, on the wealthy.

We offer this research in order to help answer important questions, not to support or oppose any specific plan or its author.

I'm apparently not explaining clearly. Using a gun to wound is just as much using deadly force under the law as using it to kill. The intent in using deadly force, whether a gun or not, is to stop a threat. If the threat dies due to the application of deadly force so be it, that is a possible result, but not the intent. So, no, you aren't "trying to kill" you are trying to stop.

Since using a gun is using deadly force, no matter where you aim, to state you felt merely wounding was "sufficient" you are essentially admitting the threat you were facing didn't actually justify using the gun to stop it at all. You should have used some other proportional, non-lethal, method. To "shoot to wound" is the actual "over-kill," as in disproportionate use of force.

I recommend Andrew Branca's "Law of Self-Defense" for a better explanation of the subject.

Most are able to work at jobs appropriate to their "skill" level with appropriate and compassionate supervision and assistance.  

The "mentally-ill" tend to be less able to function in the "day to day" world.  They need both supportive placement and counseling/therapy and, often, psychotropic medication.  Very few mentally-ill individuals recognize, acknowledge and voluntarily seek help for their illness without significant support from family, friends and health care agencies

Missed layups, wild shots, and worst of all, bad passes contributed to the loss.  UAA kept trying to throw over the top of far taller players resulting in too many turnovers. As a practicing physician I find several things about this situation  to be questionable. The regulations about tramadol changed almost 2 years ago. To be prescribing it and not to be aware of this is an error of exceptional proportions. It suggests that the prescriber is not adequately familiar with the medication. Tramadol is not a risk free medication. It has been known to cause seizures and induce delirium. Using it to treat opiate withdrawal is not medically supportable with the current information base. It is not approved for this purpose and there are no studies of adequate quality to justify its use in this way.
Additionally, having a provider with no DEA certification prescribing medications for the relief of  substance withdrawal is not acceptable practice. The medications used to treat alcohol withdrawal, in particular,  have ALWAYS required it.
More investigation needs to be done regarding the safety, validity and effectiveness  of the treatment that these clinics provide.

Actually, Christiansen is right. I worked 2 years as a student worker at UAA. I made just above minimum wage, so I wasn't one of these folks, but let me cover just how the system works.

A student worker isn't required to actually be a full-time student, they only have to be half-time (6 credit hours per semester) to remain employed. During the semester, they're limited to 20 hours per week, but during breaks, including summer, they are allowed 40 hours per week.
A lot of student workers don't actually receive credit for work. I didn't despite my job being related to my degree. There are also no benefits such as reduced costs/fees, and no benefits such as medical (though as a student you can give your check back to buy student healthcare insurance, still at full price).

In order to have a system that works, we have to have rational laws and a widely known process for checking up on these people. We don't seem to have that process, and I think part of the problem in developing one is the distrust between both sides of the gun ownership issue. Substantial funding for studies on Japanese tsunami debris and its biota has been provided by the Ministry of the Environment in Japan through PICES. My funding is for the algae.  The algae make up 68 of the ~200 identified species on debris– and about 66% of these are already reported to occur in the NE Pacific.  Some of these are natural distributions and some are from earlier invasions.  In many cases, the genetic strains found in our waters vary slightly from those found on debris.  Currently, our algal project is doing comparative sequencing of these species to determine if the sources of our resident species are from debris or from Asia or elsewhere around the globe.  It has long been recognized that species are transported by currents from Japan to the NE Pacific.  But, the rate of transport has increased dramatically with debris from the tsunami.  About 75% of the arriving algal species are reproductive (on the debris), and it will be astonishing if none recruit in our waters.

They have us in a bind because they understand that they are the only employers that will be flexible about our class schedules. What was the biggest climate change event in the last one million years on earth? I would say it was the melting of the vast ice sheets covering much of the northern hemisphere. When this happened an area much larger than today's Alaska disappeared as sea level rose from all of the melted glacial ice.
Although there were small groups of humans around for the tail-end of the Ice Age the knowledge of the fact that there WAS an Ice Age became lost to human memory and knowledge. We simply forgot that it ever happened at all and the Great Ice Age was only rediscovered in the 1850's. And of course those that first proposed that much of the planet was shaped by moving ice were laughed at by "deniers" who believed the earth was shaped by the Biblical Flood. Some would say the science of climate change started with those debates. We are only beginning to learn how the climate effects our world and our lives. Stay tuned in for more....

The high school I attended in England is as large as any of our community college campuses. There were 2000 students in my graduating class alone. This put me 4 years behind them as I skipped 7th grade which put me in AE, which was a cruel joke. The average class size was 30, and some went to 37. Every one of my competent teachers managed to carry their workload, and get me up to speed inside of 1 month. Most of our educators cannot teach at this level, and this is why larger class sizes hurt our system when larger class sizes assure proper funding. England was preparing me for college at 17 with the tools I would need in classes of 100+ students, and tests are how I earn a degree. I'm speaking from experience, well knowledge on Piling Higher Deeper BS.

There is an excellent TED talk about what makes the best cities in the world;  Public spaces that are inviting- they need benches with wide enough seats and backs to be comfortable for more than a minute or two.  They need to have foliage, beauty,  places where one can linger and people watch, read, reflect, rest.  The city center should be public, this is key to having an inviting city, a city with heart.   The question I keep asking is how do we make it work for all people, the advantaged and the disadvantaged?  And the follow up question which digs into a much more difficult issue;  How do we help those who are struggling/disadvantaged get on their feet? The scientific name is Orcinus Orca. The term "killer whale" comes from a sub type known as "transients." They eat seals, other whales and have even been known to attack sharks. Hence, giving them the name "killer whale." The other types are called "residents." They do not prey on anything other than salmon, and fish. The movie didn't help with the plight of orcas either. It made them out to be "killers," when in fact no human has been known to be attacked in the wild. It only happens in captivity.

Spirit Guide:   It's true that ONE on the issues causing such widespread is the shortage of "affordable" housing.  Putting all those others aside for a moment, may I suggest that in today's economy, private sector affordable housing is virtually impossible.  In nearly all communities, Eugene is a good example, lots, permits and SDFs (system development fees) are so high that a builder has invested 70K or more before even starting to build.  The "rule of thumb" is a home being constructed cost at least one to two times the cost of the lot.  So, it's seldom you'll see a new home for less than 150K.  Existing homes, unless you're talking a real "dingbat" are no cheaper.

Rentals are no cheaper.  They're premised on a) the cost of the apartments and b) the pool of renters.  There's, unfortunately very little available for minimum wage level working class families or, even, individuals.  

BTW: those "little houses" are cute, but at the cost of lots, they're no answer either.

Ron Bevirt nailed it. The city planning staff are promoting this radical transformation of modest, single-family homes by claims it will foster a "20-minute neighborhood" and prevent sprawl.
 
I challenge proponents to point to the following evidence:

* A capacity analysis that projects how many additional residents could be accommodated with the zone change versus existing code.

* A traffic analysis.

* A "carbon impact" analysis.

* Worst-case "Sketchup" (3-D) visual models of allowable structure mass and parking under the new zoning standards.

* An analysis of impacts on current owner-occupants.

* The results of contacting every property owner and determining whether they favor or oppose the zone change.

So far, all that the staff and proponents have relied upon are generalized, bumper-sticker assumptions.

All of the above analyses can be done with a reasonable amount of effort. In fact, most of them have already been done by city staff in relation to other broad zone changes.

The Wilderness Society's contention that the Sustainable Trails Coalition bill would "allow use of motorized vehicles" is false. If the editorial writer had looked further, he or she would have seen that the bill calls only for limited bicycle and baby-stroller access (baby strollers are also banned from federal Wilderness areas). Bicycles and baby strollers would be allowed only where the local forest rangers say a trail or trails can accommodate them. This is not radical stuff.

With regard to "mechanized tools," STC's proposed bill would remind federal agencies that they can use chainsaws to clear tree deadfalls and blowdowns. The agencies already have that authority under the Wilderness Act of 1964, but for some odd reason they've convinced themselves they don't. The result is thousands of miles of overgrown or vanished trails all over the United States, with Wilderness areas being abandoned by legitimate users and marijuana growers taking their place.

A key difference between the "tech jobs" and jobs generated by the timber industry is that the timber jobs (and other natural resource jobs, i.e. agriculture) are tied to a geographic location.  Tech jobs are not.  While it is easy to say that this offers the environment that the new tech industry prefers or there is a good supply of trained workers or whatever, the fact is they can locate almost anywhere.  I think you heard this same optimism in past years when names such as Sony or the chip maker is west Eugene moved in.  Maybe this new wave of tech will be different?  I'm more encouraged by the new wood products (large beams) that are being produced in the area as a long term economic benefit.

That winter of '76-'77 was the first year anyone could ever remember Kenai Lake not freezing at all in the winter let alone freeze thick enough to drive on. That warmth may have allowed the Spruce Bark Beetles to live through he winter and begin the devastation of Kenai Peninsula spruce forests. After that astonishing lack of ice in 1977 the lake at the Primrose to Lawing end has remained ice free for 10 more winters including this remarkably warm year. It's a pattern and not just an El Nino event. I have Crocuses blooming in beds that are normally ice and snow covered this time of year. Sitting on the deck in Eagle River right now at 7:30 pm on April 12 soaking up the 62 degree warmth with my contended dogs. This is the new normal I'm thinking.

The 1967 discovery of large oil reserves on state-owned land in the Prudhoe Bay area of Alaska resulted in a windfall to the State. The State, which had a total budget of $124 million in 1969, before the oil revenues began to flow into the state coffers, received $3.7 billion in petroleum revenues during the 1981 fiscal year. [Footnote 1] This income will continue, and...

The discovery of oil at Prudhoe Bay in 1968 and the 1973 Oil Crisis in response to the Yom Kippur War played a large role in Egan's second governorship, as demand for oil increasingly played a role in the state's politics. In the later months of 1973, President Richard Nixon signed the Trans-Alaska Pipeline Authorization Act, an act to reduce American dependence on OAPEC oil. Many environmental politicians in the state bitterly opposed this federal legislation during the second Egan governorship.

ADF&G sets harvest numbers which are based upon the current species population and a management plan. All members of the public have ability to contribute to forming a management plan.

That is not at all true Melissa.  This is extremely bad legal advice that you are giving.  Discharging a firearm within city limits is highly illegal.  It is called Unlawful Use of a Weapon, and is a Class C felony.   The circumstances are much different under Oregon law when one is shooting a gun inside a residential neighborhood, compared to shooting on a farm that is outside the city's limits.

There are only 3 very limited exceptions under Oregon Law that allow one to legally discharge a gun inside city limits.   It can only be done if you are (1) trying to stop a person that is committing a felony involving violent force   (2) a burglary is being committed inside a dwelling  and (3) unlawful deadly physical force is being used, or about to be used, against a person

THERE ARE NO OTHER EXCEPTIONS under Oregon law.   The relevant statutes are Oregon Revised Statutes 166.220 and 166.219, if you would like to look the law up.

Shooting a gun inside city limits is a BIG NO-NO.

Kris Anne Hall's case that there is no constitutional authorization for federal land ownership can be debunked by a simple reading of the plain english of the U.S. Constitution's "Property Clause"; Article IV, §3, Clause 2:

"The Congress shall have Power to dispose of and make all needful Rules and Regulations respecting the Territory or other Property belonging to the United States."

Nor does the plain english of the "Equal Footing Doctrine" Article IV, § 3, Clause 1, have anything to do with proscribing Federal land ownership:

“New States may be admitted by the Congress into this Union; but no new State shall be formed or erected within the Jurisdiction of any other State; nor any State be formed by the Junction of two or more States, or Parts of States, without the Consent of the Legislatures of the States concerned as well as of the Congress.”

230 years of Supreme Court rulings and precedents confirms this.

Support your position or change it.

Most States set up lab testing when they legalized medical marijuana.  We did not.  The testing really is to benefit patients who need to be able to identify cannabinoids and terpenes of interest and standardize a dose.  Some of these folks are medically fragile (cancer, AIDs) and shouldn't be exposed to virulent pathogens (bacteria, mold).  The pesticide testing is a lot more expensive and it's utility is more shady.  It's never been clear that pesticides are in use or have ever caused any health problems.  The main pesticide they discovered in Colorado (Eagle 20) is a common mold inhibitor sprayed on all kinds of produce, but the rub is that it is approved to be eaten, not smoked due to the metabolic pathway.

The problem is that tens of millions of adult Americans work for less than a living wage.  I work in a production environment.  My job doesn't require a degree, but we have to do math, and we have to be focused.  There are no teenagers at my workplace.  Most of us are middle-aged, experienced people with a good work ethic.  When someone comes in who's not so bright, or has bad work habits, they get cycled out very quickly.  Yet most of us earn less than $12 per hour.  Our economy has devolved to the point where employers can have grownups for a teenager's wage.  It's nice for them, but not so good for the employees, or for society.

We could have a low teenage wage, or a low first 30-days on the job wage.  If it's really a job that requires no knowledge and no experience, then those employers will be okay with kids and high-turnover adults.  Employers who want grownups should pay a living wage.  A full-time worker should be able to rent an apartment.

It was warmer when the continental ice sheets melted between 14,000 to 10,000 years ago. Some estimates are that much of the melting occurred within a span of between 50 and 100 years. The effects were catastrophic. In Western Montana a continental ice lobe created Lake Missoula, an inland sea. When  the lobe of the continental ice sheet melted catastrophic floods occurred. The huge release of water scoured all of the soil, vegetation and fauna from the affected land, creating the present Columbia River Scablands. In the region that now contains the Great Lakes, another huge inland sea was created by the continental ice sheet. When it too broke through the ice 11,500 years ago the combined sea level increases were enough to cause the Mediterranean to breach the Straits of Bosphorus and flood the Black sea fresh water lake that was 600 feet lower than today. If the Antarctic and Greenland ice sheets collapse, a 222 foot sea rise would flood inland hundreds of miles in lowland regions.

Group selectivity dictates we have in us a very strong urge to agree with one another and to identify as a group. The problem in politics is that your in a room with people who are supposed to be representatives of groups, not identifying as a group unto themselves and seeking to agree with one another. Why?

Because reason begins with disagreement not agreement. Laws of physics are not things we prove, they are things we cannot disprove yet cannot observe without fail, i.e. we disprove everything we can and whatever is left is assumed to be "truth". Reason is a process of analytical deduction and it is the basis of pretty much anything which pretends to surpass the bias of our own subjective agreements, and the multiple failures it requires are responsible for every breakthrough....ever.

My neighborhood association, Arnold Creek, came up with a different way to restrict who can vote on Association matters.  To be eligible to vote, one has to attend a meeting within the preceding 6 months (of the vote) and annually thereafter.

Those who oppose any taxes or use of the permanent fund earnings to balance the state budget seem to believe the state can cut more spending.  While that's almost certainly the case (i.e stop wasting money on the Knik Arm Bridge and other mega-projects that make no economic sense), everyone who's looked at the numbers says there is no way to balance the budget through spending cuts alone.  Most of us use public highways, send our children to public schools,  use the airport, buy food and supplies that arrive through the port of Anchorage, and depend on state funding to provide these and many other services.  In most states, people pay taxes to pay for those services.  We've had a free ride for a long time, and apparently some of us have gotten used to having these services provided for free.  What's really sad is that our elected representatives apparently believe that most of us fit that description and will vote them out of office if they act responsibly to deal with the situation.

Attorney General Richards told House Finance. “By degrading the value of the Fund in real terms, you also degrade the value of the cash flow that goes to the government over time.”

The PF Board's long-term investment goal for the Fund is to achieve a real rate of return of five percent (5%) per year.  Since 1993 the PF has seen a return of about 5.9%. The ordinance will be appealed as a violation of free speech. The courts will take guidance from the Oregon Supreme Court case of Robertson v. State of Oregon. They will examine the stated purpose of the ordinance ("the safe and efficient flow of vehicular traffic") and what the ordinance restricts ("giv[ing] or relinquish[ing] possession or control of … any item of property to a pedestrian"). They will determine that the ordinance restricts some forms of free speech (giving money to panhandlers) but not others (a lost driver asking for directions, or two drivers stopping to chat). They will find the ordinance unconstitutional, as both forms of speech have exactly the same impact on the flow of traffic. To be legal, Springfield would have to make it illegal to stop for any reason.

Legal summary: http://legalpubs.osbar.org/2014/06/25/free-speech-in-oregon/

Full legal opinion: http://law.justia.com/cases/oregon/supreme-court/1982/293-or-402-0.html

The part about extending the statute of limitations is a predictable but unfortunate emotional response.  Why did wise legislators in the past enact statutes of limitation on any crime??  Because they did not care about justice?  No.  Statutes of limitation were enacted for the sake of justice in recognition of the fact that as time passes facts become less clear, memories fade, and justice, real justice becomes impossible.  Rape in particular is an emotional crime.  To a very real extent, those charged must prove their innocence rather than be proved guilty.  As the years go by, a person charged with rape loses the ability to defend himself.  Alibis disappear as potential witnesses forget or die, etc.  The more time passed the surer the conviction

Counties are to receive 10% and cities 10%. So there will be $8.4 million going to the 36 counties and if Lane receives 10% (we are roughly 10% of the state population) of that it would be $840,000 to compensate for the increased costs on the County like special DUII training of deputies, etc.

The state is in a budget crisis and this is what we're worrying about?  Look I get it, no one likes having to change their clock radio twice a year.  And its a fair statement that its not real clear what advantage DST gives us in Alaska.  All fair statements.  But the truth is that changing our time requires a massive investment in overhaul of everything computerized in the state.  Every cell phone, every laptop, every bank application, every control system whether its valves on a pipeline or street lights or air traffic control has daylight savings time programmed into it and would require a 'fix' to resolve it.  Some of those fixes would be relatively simple; some would be extremely complicated.  This issue is a solution looking for a problem to solve.  Honestly, don't we have more pressing things to worry about right now?

This was solved quite a while back and the first form of the solution is now in use. When the sun is shining (and the wind is blowing) such that power production exceeds demand, water is pumped uphill into reservoirs. When the sun goes down (or the wind stops blowing)  and demand exceeds power supply, this water is allowed to flow down through turbines to provide power.

There are other storage options coming on line, such as the growing electric car market (currently confined almost exclusively to California, the state with the lowest energy use per capita). These car batteries can be used to buffer demand bumps. There are also other large scale battery systems coming on line, but none of them are as efficient as pumped water storage.

Each voter has, typically, only two choices for each legislative office--one typically a compromised but familiar incumbent and the other typically an unknown.  The incumbent, regardless of party, invariably has campaign donations from oil, the unknown does only if s/he's in effect a candidate sponsored by outside interests.  With this range of choices, no intelligent voter can do anything but make the least rancid choice.  As a result, serious reform never gets off the ground in Alaska.  

What could conceivably change this is a public-interest vetting organization that proposed a reform slate across many different districts.  It wouldn't have too much effect in the first election or two.  But if it gained credibility, candidates would find themselves competing for its approval.  Then voters in different districts could vote for even unknown reform candidates with some hope that voters in other districts would do the same.

It's not reasonable to call out divorce on its own (or blame women for initiating divorces.) Divorce, while considered an ACE, is not necessarily harmful to development. In fact, supportive parenting through a stressful time (like divorce) can promote resilience in children. Also, as motleycrew suggested, divorce can be an adaptive choice for people in abusive relationships. A point well taken from this article is that any one ACE doesn't mean that a child will have poor outcomes. When negative experiences begin to add up, however, is when poor mental and physical health outcomes arise.

Sunday’s article about the physical challenges of aging showed up just when I needed it.  You put into words exactly what I have been feeling – that despite my best efforts and a positive attitude, my body is betraying me.  I have been a (relatively) active walker for the past 30 years.  Now, at age 70, I’m relegated to a gentle workout on a stationary bike and am anticipating knee surgery in July.  This whole scenario has made me feel very inferior to those “gray-haired ladies” who charge up mountainsides at age 75 or more! 
 
Seeing you put those same thoughts into print was a big encouragement to me!  Best wishes for your surgery and following recovery.
  Katherine S.

Thank you Shannyn! Also to be considered here is the very obvious way in which this company was avoiding any local hire. The "test" would be a welding certification test which could be taken either in Anchorage or Fairbanks. The employer could very simply arrange for local employees to be tested by calling a lab in either location and telling them what procedure they wanted the welder to be certified for. Another alternative is for the onsite welding inspector to test incoming hires which as an inspector I did many times myself. By requiring prospective employees to travel to Louisiana to take the test they are effectively ruling out any local hire as well as bypassing our own test labs who could probably use the contract. I traveled all over the U.S. working in certified welding jobs and the certification test was always given on site or in the nearest city. There needs to be a way to enforce local hire when Outside contractors are used by oil companies.

I don't necessarily agree with this situation (locking the gates) but the Condo owners pay a lot of money to maintain a green-way and pier structure so  perhaps a little less vitriol would be in order.  Calling for more police enforcement is not out of order.

The military system, unlike the academic side of the U of O, more closely approaches a meritocracy.  There are conditions, tasks and standards which must be met to succeed.  The sports side also has that sort of system.  One is required to meet or exceed standards or you lose your position, whether as a player or as a coach.  The academic standards are subject to less rigor and certainty, based on my experience as a student.  They more closely match with the rest of societies' concept of 'sucking up'.  To get a good 'grade' one is required to parrot the information nearest and dearest to the heart of the instructors involved.  I am given to understand that there is also a thing known as 'grade inflation' which is a corollary of the Lake Woebegone Principle that 'everyone is above average'.  Those who successfully parrot the appropriate information are all then found to be in the highest percentile.  These tendencies are most prevalent in the squishy 'sciences', of course.

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights was approved by the United Nations General Assembly in 1948.  The United States not only voted to approve this document, but the document itself was largely drafted by Eleanor Roosevelt.  Among the human rights enumerated in the Declaration in 1948 are these:  "Everyone has the right to a standard of living adequate for the health and well-being of himself and of his family, including food, clothing, housing and medical care and necessary social services, and the right to security in the event of unemployment, sickness, disability, widowhood, old age or other lack of livelihood in circumstances beyond his control."  There is also a human right to education, to work, and to just and adequate remuneration for work.  The full list of human rights can be found on http://www.un.org/en/universal-declaration-human-rights/.

To fly into Cold Bay and on to King Cove is to view an incredible absurdity that gets more distorted as one gets farther away. Approaching Cold Bay you can't help but notice roads all over the tundra. You can rent a car and drive all over the refuge. Nobody ever seems to note this odd fact. The Cold Bay airport is like landing in Anchorage but without any buildings. Anything that flies can land there. Then you must take a very brief flight—only a few minutes—to land in a muddy hole between two mountains. Hunters fly in to rent cars and shoot ducks and strangely enough, the only place they can't go is the town next door. It's truly bizarre that anybody with time and cash can do exactly the thing the environmentalists claim will irrevocably damage the refuge if the locals are allowed to do it.

As a teacher of color  who works at Harrison Park, I have to respectfully disagree with Emily Toll.  It is sad that teachers (mostly Caucasian) think they know what is best for minority students.  As a child, I had the experience of being in ESL classes for four years of my early education and had to miss electives, such as music, PE, and art. However, I would not trade what I learned in ESL for these enhancement classes.  These classes would not have helped me pass my exams in high school, the SAT, or getting a scholarship in college.  As I am able to converse in another language, I am able to talk to parents in their own language on a more personable level.  Most, if not all parents, expressed that they prefer to have their child(ren) in ESL.  This is the general consensus among minority parents in any language.  To say that John Walden did not solicit input from ESL parents is disrespectful and slanderous.  Students need to read, write, and do math--that is an equitable education.
